I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Alright, so here's the scoop: I'm a huge fan of the Sims, and, like most of the other reviewers, I've seen the evolution of Sims games. Sims 3 was absolutely phenomenal - I loved it! When Sims 4 was announced, I hopped on the hype train, ready to have a great experience. But I didn't. What a lot of people don't know, is that The Sims 4 launched missing several key features from previous installments including the removal of the "Toddler" life state, and the removal of family trees. Traits have been pruned into the oblivion, so with the base game you only get about 15 to choose from as opposed to the 30-40 from the base game of 3. Some of the missing features were eventually patched in after EA received a lot of backlash for it, but the game still feels empty. == Pros == *A LOT less lag than Sims 3 - my worlds don't take 15 minutes to load. *Graphics are more vibrant than they were in previous titles. *Build Mode has been greatly improved, and allows for a much better experiencing when creating homes and buildings. *Sims now have moods that affect their actions and how they interact with others - i.e. angry sims stomp around, and scared sims have the option to take a "nervous poop". == Cons == *One of the best and most interesting things about The Sims 3 was that the map was much more open world. Zoom out of your house and see whose visiting the local parks, the community pool, entering and exiting buildings. You could control your sims even if they're all the way across town. The Sims 4 does not let you do this. Neighborhoods are sectioned off, so each one has a loading screen when travelling between them. If you go to visit a gym in another neighborhood, you have to take control of either that sim alone at the gym, or the rest of the family back home. You can switch between whose active, but you can't control both at the same time. *A lot of furniture and items that were available in the base game of Sims 3 are now locked behind DLCs. *Several years later, I noticed bugs where I command my Sim to do something, and they just stand there, staring at nothing. This sometimes requires a restart if it goes on for too long. *You can no longer control your pets. This is one of my least favorite changes between 3 and 4. In Sims 3, you had the ability to control your pets. *There's a lot less life states to play as in this game - 3 had pixies, witches, werewolves, vampires, and genies which all had their own unique wishes, lifestyles, and gameplay elements. *You can no longer create custom patterns or choose colors from a color wheel when in Create-a-Sim, or when placing furniture. You are bound to whatever choices of colors there are by default. This absolutely murdered creativity. The Sims 4, although I enjoy playing it and creating Sims and homes, is a shell of it's former self. Do yourselves a favor, only buy this game when it's on sale, especially the DLC. There's over $1000 worth of DLC now, with some of the DLC costing as much as the game itself, if not more. EA should be ashamed of their business models in nearly every game they've released in the past 10 years. Disgraceful.

Ok, so, sims 4 base game. I never played any of the older franchise. I just dive right onto the latest , i've had this first on console but switched to pc instead :D  .I can say that it's fun specially now that, First- it can drop its price at a friggin 88% off when sale, (i bought it on full price back then btw, both on console and pc). Second- Now, this year, surprisingly has been very interesting and- enjoyable i must admit. Aside from the dlcs always on sale ,(but still pricey), they are constantly adding something new to the base game. And now with the new update that adds more realism? I mean, before, your sims LIFE is like so perfect with just little moodlets to let them down, and everything is just so perfectly boring and it lacks more interaction and stuff like u know, gameplay? I mostly just spend time on build mode. Now with their new update, neighbors can have their own stories and drama-YOUR household CAN have more drama, and it can be a total mess! (happened to me apparently) Its just small autonomy stuff and you're totally in control if you dont want it,but it added more life to the game! And of course the new sim delivery, new scenario(which i never tried), and basically new gameplay. They added more color swatches last year to some base game outfits and to some build items as well. (maxis have been quite active this past year) there is so much going on now that i have to spend more time on live mode than i ever did. Maybe thats why im posting a review just now. i'm always finding something new lately on cas or build mode. they keep updating the game to make it more immersive than it used to be. and i appreciate that. BUT of course it will be much more fun when you add some of its DLC :) ps: i only buy dlc when its on sale, cause even in 50% off-its still a bit pricey alright. Anyway, i just hope EA continue to add more good stuff to the base game. Peace... ;)

After the unapologetically bugged Sims 3, I honestly thought it couldn't get worse with Sims 4, but EA has not failed to surprise. Actually I let EA surprise me despite my better judgment. This garbage was released in 2014, and so little work obviously went into polishing and straightening out. 1 minute in: The end of first day. He goes to bed. I thought he would wake up when he was fully rested or something and intentionally didn't force him to wake up, I let him sleep as long as he wanted. A little too much couldn't hurt. He sleeps for about 20 hours straight and consequently woke up famished and immediately peed himself. 10 minutes in: I make him wake up (of course). He does wake up (good for EA), but the sleep icon bottom-left doesn't go away. It just stays there. I can do other things, but it just won't go away. OK. Whatever. EA after all. What did I expect? Then I do some stuff, days pass: It stays there. Doesn't cause any inconvenience other than the impression it gives that EA doesn't disappoint. OK. Whatever. 25 minutes in: Now another icon gets stuck there right on top of the sleep icon. Again it doesn't affect the gameplay. I'll let it slide this time, too. 30 minutes in: Next day. He eats. I order him to clean up his plate. The icon disappears about a second after it looks like he's going to do it. Then he just stops. Minds his business. Clean up the plate, please? Again the same thing. He won't do it. OK. Whatever. I can place the darn plate in the trash myself. Problem solved, right? Bunch of hours in: The stuck icons go away when I save and exit. Maybe that has to do with him not doing what I told him to do. I can just save and exit every time the icon gets stuck. The two bugs turn out to be unrelated. No activity icons are stuck, but he still persistently won't  clean up his plate OR take out the trash. Or rather, he takes the trash and drops it before leaving the house EVERY SINGLE TIME. Hmm. OK.. 6 hours in: Certain actions randomly become undoable just whenever. It would be tolerable perhaps if this bug was limited to minor actions like cleaning up, but now he won't go to work. I spent half an hour trying to make him go to work. Saved and exited multiple times. Nothing works. Finally: I start a new game. Maybe something was wrong with the previous one. A car was stuck somewhere in town? A fish tried to hop out of the water but couldn't so the game understandably had to go haywire? The usual Sims 3 circus shenanigans could be happening and breaking the game. I start a new game. My sim goes to bed at the end of the day. I let him sleep until the bar is fully green, and I tell him to wake up in the morning. 3 hours until his shift. We got stuff to do before that. He won't wake up. I break the wake up command. He sleeps like a baby. He has been sleeping now for close to 2 days, and I guess he's about to die peacefully in his sleep. Soon he'll be out of his misery at least. EA, my dears. You deliievered a most fantastical disappointment. I honestly didn't think you guys could outdo yourselves in the embarrasment department. Bye forever. Tl;dr: Don't buy Sims 4.

At this point I am PISSED. The game is free by now, which is nice, but the DLCs are just WAY overpriced. Recently there have been some updates instead of only adding new and expensive DLCs, which in theory sounds nice. However, the recent updates have just included loads of bugs imo (fe: My Infant doesn't sleep in its crib but is glued to their caretakers feet and slides over the floor while sleeping. This one is still kinda funny cause it doesn't really interrupt the gameplay, but after about an hour of playing and changing between build-mode and live-mode the game just freezes and i have to start over (yes I have uninstalled all mods and deleted & reinstalles the game). Theres also the general frustration with updates contents: Why would i want an infant sim? Its just a toddler that cannot do anything (yeah i guess realism but theres SO much they could've added so why?) Could've just made it a free DLC instead so everyone who wants it can install it and everyone who doesnt isn't forced to. Also whats with the Infants positions in the clothes changing menu? I can't even see half the clothes and If you select pants they just point their booties at u which is kinda weird and like i wanna style an outfit, not only their bum). Imo EA is just trying to farm as much money as they can from Sims (which btw is not a new problem, as u can see it in sims 3 aswell). That is really sad cause in theory, it would be a great game but all the money grabbing is just making me feel really frustrated. TLDR: DLCs are expensive af, recent updates have been more annoying than helpful/ nice. Imo EA is just trying to farm as much money as they can from Sims, but recently noticed that people are getting more and more annoyed so they drop useless updates to make some people happy.

Don't. I've spent almost or about $1000 on this series. I've played it for thousands of hours. I transferred my game over from Origin because Origin sucks. My hours on Steam do not reflect the hours of my life I've given to this game. Every single time, as of a few months ago, that I want to boot up this game I stop myself. I know I will be enjoying myself and run into something game breaking. Look, I have been playing The Sims religiously since Sims 1, buying all the expansions. Been playing this series religiously since I was a teenager well into adulthood. Sims 1. Sims 2. Sims 3. And all the little expansions. While the games could always get buggy and weird I had faith that the developers would work it out. The Sims 4 is unplayable for me at times. In fact, back in November of last year (2021) it became COMPLETELY unplayable, with Sims freezing and doing nothing. This happens too often. TOO OFTEN!!! I can't enjoy this game anymore!!!! Things are not getting fixed and I'm MAD about it! I've spent too much money and TIME for it to be such a bad experience almost every time I boot this game up. The Sims 5???? I don't want it!!! FIX THIS GAME!

Would I recommend this game? That's a very tough call to make. Did I spend more than 600 hours in this game and enjoyed it a lot? Absoluelty! Did I spend several hundred of Euros (yes, even with good sales)? Yep. If you are a hardcore Sims Fan you will love this game, because you always did. But you are also most likely to have this game and all it's ridiculous DLC allready in your library. But if you are new to it and just wanted to start, RUN! Don't jump into this rabbithole (Ah I miss those from the told Sims 3 times) and go for something less time and money consuming. I don't know, Stardew Valley or something. Sims 4 definitly has some good features it's predicors didn't have and after 8 years it's finally decent and producers seem to listen for once. But really, don't invest your emotions, money and time in this beautiful mess, if you don't have to.

IMPORTANT: THE SIMS 4 BASE GAME IS BECOMING FREE TO PLAY ON OCTOBER 18. (THE DLC WILL STILL BE PAID) THE ONLY COMPENSATION YOU GET FOR BUYING THE GAME RIGHT NOW IS A $5 KIT GIVEN FOR FREE. IF YOU ASK ME, ITS NOT WORTH BUYING AT ALL (ALSO A SLAP ON THE FACE OF FELLOW SIMMERS WHO BOUGHT THE GAME FOR 40 BUCKS) . JUST WAIT FOR THE GAME TO BECOME FREE, AND INSTEAD USE YOUR MONEY ON AN EXPANSION PACK. Sims 4 is a good game, but it doesn't stand out very well compared to it's predecessors. Sure, it's pretty great it in it's own ways, it allows some level of multi-tasking, Sims becoming more expressful, it's attractive cartoonish art style, however, it's unfair DLC pricing and cut content from the previous games, including handful of animations is very disappointing. Has it improved from launch? Quite a lot. Is it worth playing without DLC? You could, but consider mods and custom content. Base game can easily get you bored, but it can give you hours of fun if you focus on completing milestones such as different aspirations and careers. I wish there was more to the base game, but even the smallest things, such as a video game console or a washing machine, are locked behind DLC paywalls. Do I recommend? Yeah sure, give it a try. I'm mostly a Sims 3 person, but I recently brought Sims 4 and it is pretty decent, have me couple of hours of fun. Tip: consider getting expansions and a few game packs only, leave the stuff packs and instead get free mods/ custom content ones....there are a huge library of good modded stuff packs available over the internet. Just a friendly tip to save your money. As well as create a sim items! Only requires base game to be installed!! A Guide for The Sims‚Ñ¢ 4 By: Dari Playing Sims 4 Vanilla without any expansions or other DLC will inevitably get you bored, but the little tips I will share from my experience will surely help you have more fun! Honestly, Sims 4 is still a pretty good game. Yes EA is milking the game dry at this point but it's still pretty neat. Aside from it's obvious flaws. The free sexual orientation update is well worth it. High School Years? Don't mention that to me.

please don't let my hours invested into this game distract you from the fact that this game is bad, actually. See, EA has me by the balls. They know I'm going to buy the DLC each and every time like an addict attempting in vain to reach that exact same high. They are fully aware that I will keep returning to this game like an abused spouse who, when seeing that tiny visual and gameplay updates that should have been included in the original launch, gets that hit of dopamine that's akin to those feelings that I first felt when we were in the honeymoon stage. I'm exhausted, my wallet is empty, and my pride has been taken out back of one of EA's corporate buildings to be shot. Anyways, the next DLC has bunnies in it so that looks fun.

This is predatory spliced up game play in its most diabolically pure form. I've only purchased the base game at a $20 discounted rate and am content with it, but what they are attempting with their $1000 DLC bundle at full price is criminal.  This game was released in September of 2014, six years ago.  It is trying to plumb $1020 from its fanbase for what is at most $120 worth of content.  Compared to Sims 3, it under delivers.  Take the Pets expansion for example; in Sim 3 you can have dogs, cats, horses, even a unicorn that could be sent out to burn down the houses of your enemies (not even joking.)  Sims 4, on the other hand, provides a "cats and dogs" expansion that simply includes cats and dogs...  Or take the Halloween themed content; in Sims 3, you could not only be a vampire, but a werewolf, fairy, a witch, wizard, or ghost.  Sims 4?  Vampires... and vampires alone is the whole expansion. Yet, in the end, neither of these titles are worth the price they are asking, especially when there are current developers in the indie circuit that far outclass the quality and quantity EA and Maxis have reduced themselves to.  Given the practices of the company and their history and their continued action, all I feel is shame in my purchase of their products and the only redeeming factor is that I've acquired said products at a severely reduced rate. 7/4/2020: Edited for spelling and punctuation

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place. Ingredients: 1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter 2. 1/2 cup white sugar 3. 1/2 cup brown sugar 4. 1/4 cup water 5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon 6. 1 pinch salt 7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced 8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie Directions: 1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C). 2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside. 3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices. 4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal. 5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust. 6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

What have you done with this game! I was a typical gamer who played variety games, including The Sims. I started this series with "The Sims 2 Castaway" on PSP, then "The Sims 2" also on PSP, then "The Sims Medieval" on PC, and finally "The Sims 4" at the premiere and as a typical gamer, I was preparing for expansions for this game, but I didn't expect how much it would cost me! I didn't know what a past this series had! I bought Expansion packs, Game packs and Stuff packs. I spent a lot of money to make this game as rich as possible, I didn't know it was a trap set by greedy EA. When I discovered Stardew Valley, I played The Sims 4 less and less, and when I heard there would be "Kits" for $5, I said ENOUGH! So little content for so much money is absurd, so I abandoned this game! And after a few years I came, to say how terrible EA is as a publisher for this series. Maybe let's start with this: what do I think about this game? It can be considered a "Cozy Life" game - we have an advanced character creator and lots of activities for our character, but there are also things that I don't like. The game is point-and-click type, so we have very limited control over our character and have to wait for him to do something or go from point A to point B (Sometimes you have to wait a very long time), but it is not everything. Why does our character learn skills too quickly? Why does our character earn too much money too quickly? Why does our character make friends with NPCs too quickly? Why are the best things so cheap? Maybe this game isn't for me anymore because it's the type of game where you can control more than one character. I rated this game negatively and not because this game is no longer for me, but because of what EA has done with this series! In the fourth part we didn't get a lot of things that came from the third part, and these mega annoying DLCs and microtransactions cost so much that you can buy several indie games! The Sims series was good in the beginning, and EA was also a good game publisher.After the success of "The Sims" this is where the real fun began, as spin-offs of this game were created, such as "The Urbz", "The Sims Bustin' Out" and console versions. Soon after, we got "The Sims 2", which one was better and in addition, we got even more spin-offs on console versions. I remember having a lot of fun with "The Sims 2 Castaway" on PSP. After "The Sims 2" came the even better "The Sims 3", this time not only on PC, but also on all previously available consoles. Even on old mobile phones and Nintendo DS. It is worth adding "The Sims Medieval", which is also a spin-off and which, apart from the PC, was also released on mobile phones and smartphones. Those were the times when it was really fun to play (unfortunately, I didn't know about all versions of the game), until "The Sims 4" came along and EA's stupidity. "The Sims 4" was graphically nice, but had much less content at launch. Additionally, we received DLC and microtransactions with little content for a high price. But the worst was yet to come.  EA has decided to withdraw all console games from online stores. However, the worst was with smartphone games - for Android we got "The Sims 3" and a nasty version of "The Sims FreePlay". And here EA did something that could be considered inexcusable! He removed "The Sims 3" on Android AND released "The Sims Mobile"! Both of these games keep the player waiting, but "The Sims Mobile" is a real evil! It causes FOMO in players, which leads to ADDICTION! WHAT HAPPENED TO YOU!!! Why do you stubbornly support "The Sims 4" and "Mobile". Why are there no spin-offs of this game! Why is "The Sims 4" free and "The Sims 3" isn't free?! What happened to "The Sims 2 Ultimate Collection"? It was free in your store and now it's gone? Greed has consumed you? Because it looks like it! Now I noticed that "The Sims 4", "The Sims Freeplay", "The Sims Mobile" are games created specifically to make as much money as possible for EA! I'm really disappointed with the direction this series is going! EA's greed and laziness should anger gamers. I'm horrified that so many players are playing this game and it has very positive reviews! I think this is the worst Cozy Life game. If you are reading this, avoid these games! Unless you're very resistant to expensive DLC and annoying microtransactions.

Pretty good game honestly, but it's not on par with it's predecessor; The Sims 3. It is a huge improvement graphically but without DLC or Mod packs, The Sims 4 is basically a 5/10. A lot of things you could do in TS3 base game is considered DLC in TS4, which you have to pay for mind you. Unfortunately or fortunately TS4 went Free To Play to encourage people to buy DLC. "Oh I got this game for free, might as well buy a few of the $1,284.19 worth of DLC." and for people who already paid for the base game, (On Origin/Steam release) we didn't get anything it really feels like a slap in the face from EA.  Which it's EA, one of the most greediest publishers on par with ActiVision. Fun Fact: Electronic Arts (EA), has been voted as the worst company several years in a row! Even without buying any DLC I think you can get a decent amount of content in TS4 (without mods). To expand without purchasing anything, you'll need to install some mods. Rumor is The Sims 5 is in development and I really hope they go above and beyond TS3, and TS4. As there are new life sims coming out this year and the next, Paralives, Inzoi. (Paralives is a passion project, and Inzoi is a realistic looking sims on steroids made by an AAA company.) So in conclusion I do recommend The Sims 4. A few hours worth without any DLC, and hundreds of hours with + Mods. „ÉÑ

The Sims‚Ñ¢ 4 Classic EA, create a game, cut 99% of content out from it, and then sell everything that was cut in very small chunks as overpriced DLCs. Don't get me wrong, I actually like this game a lot. Gameplay loop is very unique, and the whole idea for it is great. I had a ton of fun playing this game alone, or with my loved ones, it's a great experience if you just want to mess around and do stupid ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. What can I say that has not already been said about this game? To me, Sims 4 is an enchanting sandbox gem that continually sparks my creativity. As a fan of the franchise, I'm smitten by the intricate customization options and lifelike personalities. The attention to detail in every aspect, from designing dream homes to shaping individual quirks, is a dream come true. The expansions and packs and many mods inject fresh adventures and careers, keeping me engaged for hours. Although some may bemoan Sims 4 over Sims 3, the game's magic remains undeniable. Overall Sims 4 is a captivating canvas where I paint stories, emotions, and endless possibilities with sheer delight. ¬≠

Everyone probably already knows this.  This game is almost the dictionary example of EA Games.  You pay for the game.  The game feels empty.  You buy an expansion to help.  It doesn't do enough so you buy another.  So on and so forth.  Except the total cost of all dlc is roughly 1400US$.  Now it would be one thing if that was in game currency; I've seen people spend that much before on games.  Hell I think I may have spent around that much collectively on Warframe back when I used to play it on PS4 (mostly for cosmetics admittedly).  But these packs are for things that feel like they should be in the base game to begin with.  Imagine paying 1500US$ for what should basically be the base game.  The only reason I own this game with a dlc pack or two is because my younger sister gave me the money to get it, and she's been the main person to play it.  I do like simulation and sandbox games, but I hate supporting developers with downright scummy business practices.  Like, do they seriously wonder why so many people pirate sims games? It also doesn't help that they killed so many smaller studios, game franchises, are too ignorant to remake Bad Company 2 or a successor, etc etc.  EA Play may be a step in the right direction but I've not experienced it for myself so I won't bother giving them that.

Even free, I cannot recommend this game. It is a buggy, inconsistent, and terrible experience brought about by either some of the worst developers in the industry, the worst business practices in the industry, or a mix of the two. My experience of five hours of the game started off fun enough, building a sim's career and forwarding it, trying to make friends, but I won't be playing further after these five hours due to a major issue, autonomy. Its either full or none, and when on full, AKA don't make me baby everyone mode, Sims naturally tend to insult each other, automatically without my consent. This is absolutely horrible game design as it sabotages any ability to create relationships in game, and tears apart preexisting ones. And to top it off with EA having the audacity to try and peddle $1000 in DLCs for this barely functioning mess, makes it potentially one of the worst games I've ever played, and EA easily still one of the worst companies.

A time sink. A money-grab. A substandard attempt at revitalising what once was a groundbreaking game series. The creation of the character is more interesting than the character's life itself. Repetitive in it's own nature. At time of review I've clocked 116.8 hours, how depressing. I feel like my own death irl would be more inspiring - man, woman, child, ghost.. it doesn't really matter which route you take, it will never be a replacement of f***ing up your own day-to-day because in this game you'll be miraculously ultra-rich in no time whether you want to be or not. Everything is too affordable. Too easy to stat max. The escapism provided is so lacklustre you'll be pining for the days of picking potatoes in your babushka's homeland where the potatoes weren't worth their weight in simoleons. Unhealthily yearning for in-game abs and perfect busts striving for anti-aging potions to preserve the obsessive negative unobtainable perfection you would be closer to perfect had you not wasted time and money on this game. When a company insists on having dozens upon dozens of add-on's and DLC at price points near-equivalent to the base game itself just for new skins or pet dynamics or whatever, having to be some sort of thousandaire or some schlup with rich parents or a middle-of-the-road inheritance to afford all of them, it really makes you wonder why they would call the base game a game at all and not just a prelude to your paychecks.

It's a lot of fun! I'd recommend waiting until there's a sale for the expansions and other packs. I plan on buying a couple more expansions on the next sale. I wish the Sims 4 had more active careers overall. I don't think the base game has any. The base game itself feels barren. I'd seriously recommend buying at least one expansion pack with it. I'll give a quick rundown of the ones I have at the moment. Seasons: this is the most popular pack for some reason. You get different holidays throughout the year, temperature affects, seasonal clothing, and some other stuff. I recommend checking out the store page to see if you like it, because it really isn't my thing. Snowy Escape: has new activities like rock climbing and skiing. You get a new snowy, Japanese-themed world to visit. My favourite part of the pack is the build/buy mode items. I turned my kitchen into a tea house! Get to Work: I've had the most fun with this, by far. I've only explored one career, but I'm excited to try the others. The Detective career is too much fun. I sent my sim out on patrol for her first day, she ran into one of her friends who beat her up. She issued them a citation on the spot. I love going out to crime scenes, getting evidence, going back to the station to analyse it. Don't even get me started on interrogations. I'll just say they're hilarious. You can also work as a doctor and a scientist. These are active jobs, so you can go to work with your sims. It's much better than waiting for their shift to end. You can also run your own retail business, but I haven't checked that out yet. Cats and Dogs: you get another active career, you can play as a vet and help sick animals! While I haven't dived too far into this pack, I am happy to say that you can have raccoons and foxes as pets! I enjoy setting up rooms for them, as well as obstacle courses outside. I believe you also get another world for this too. Get Together: I do not understand why so many reviewers don't care for this one. You get a beautiful, European-inspired town and the ability to make clubs. I didn't think much of the clubs until I made one. Once you've made your club, you can decide on what activities you want your club to do -and there's A LOT of options. The best part? Those activities are not set in stone. When I feel like meeting up with my club at the gym, I can remove activities to add in working out and yoga. If I feel like meeting up at a nightclub, I can swap out anything I want for dancing, DJing, drinking and eating. The best part about clubs? You earn points from each gathering to buy a variety of perks. You can decide whether your club has a bad rep, neutral, or good reputation. You can buy perks that allow you to increase certain skill gains from activities faster. You can also buy points to set the club 'vibe' -which is how the whole group feels. So let's say you want to send your club to the gym, you can set the club vibe to energized. If you want to boost your comedy skills, you can set the club vibe to playful. Here's a tip, you can change club vibes by talking to a sim in your club, going to club > set club vibe and select what you want. I seriously love this expansion. City Living: I don't know how I feel about this one. I like the new world they added. It has cute little kareoke bars and lounges, as well as hosting several festivals throughout the year. The create a sim options have more cultural diversity (I think that's my favourite part), If you're into it, you can live in an apartment within the world. I hate to say it, but I think this is the least impressive expansion. The aesthetic is beautiful, but it feels like there should be more to do in a city. Hopefully this helps you. I know the pages will give you a better idea of what you're getting into, but then again, some of them can be vague. I think on the next sale, I'll be buying Island Living or Get Famous.

Seriously though the base game is dry, just play the sims 3, and when EA finally thinks of way to improve it they slap a $40-$60 AUD price tag on it, and provide the smallest amount of content and MAYBE a fully functioning gameplay feature, they expect you to praise them for the grace of news skills and you're more likely to get more bugs then quality of life updates. The base game is basically a trap to get you to buy the dlc, it doesn't completely suck. it has just enough to drip you potential every now and then, to keep you playing long enough to want more, and then you grab a dlc on sale (only get them on sale if you're buying any of them), and the process starts again until the sunk cost fallacy kicks in and keeps you around. And in my opinion this is so much worse then it just being a terrible game straight up. The worst aspect of the Sims 4 is the fact that Sims 2 and 3 existed and were so beautifully done. The Sims 4 is classic EA - limiting base game and forcing you to get expansion packs to make the game remotely worth playing. Even then, at least the Sims 2 and 3's expansions were supplementary/complementary. There was so much content in the former editions that purchasing an expansion seemed like you were buying a whole other game, Yet, Sims 4 is just a weak rehashing of the Sims 2 and 3. Several bugs, missed opportunities, removed features, small maps, loading screens, superficial and limited game play, etc, etc. The advertisements for Sims 4 promoted "you rule" yet there are very few instances in which players have full control/rule over the game. It's sad that such an amazing series has come to this (i.e., reproducing Sims 2 and 3 in a much weaker format and expensive expansions). Do yourself a favor and don't spend your money on this game or expansions. Let's hope that Sims 4 is a learning opportunity for EA and that Sims 5 (if ever) addresses its shortcomings.

After being a loyal SIMS fan for many years (SIMS 2, 3 and 4), I am sick and tired of the failures which constantly prevent me from playing my game. There is no open world available like ANY of the previous titles. You get a bland illustrated map with a handful of options. With no open world available, there's no way to actually build an interactive neighborhood. It's absolutely ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• soulless. This is a AAA title, and when you get to the world menu, it looks like a copy-pasted mobile game. EA has once again, proved that their greed wins out in the end every time without fail. This is a bare-bones experience, ESPECIALLY without any content packs. Go back to any of the previous titles, avoid this at all costs, sail the seas if you need to, because even free games by EA aren't worth your time.

Sims 4 is a perfectly mediocre Sims game marred by EA's incessant need to monetize every little aspect of their games. The greed is glaringly obvious six years after it's release Sims 4 still continues to get small nuance patches tailgating large expensive content bundles. Gameplay is what you expect of a Sims game. The emotion system is interesting, but due to the lack of content in the base game, gets left out to dry. Building has it's quirks but is more in-depth this time around helping to keep the floundering base game afloat. Fun but at it's core a money sink. Not recommended even on sale; unless you have played a Sims game before and are prepared to purchase additional content every few months.

Origin Launcher bad :( Unfortunately I cannot recommend the steam edition because in typical EA fashion they force users to use their terrible Origin. As much as I enjoy this game, having played the Franchise since the beginning, I've purchased TS4 on PS4 & On the Origin store because originally you could only purchase this game there. Another annoying thing, platforms that force users into using it by buying up games (ahem EPIC.. ahem). When The Sims 4 hit the Steam marketplace it was no big decision, I knew I had to buy it. Steam is my one and only launcher. Unfortunately you are not buying The Sims 4 on Steam, instead you are just buying an Origin code for the game which is activated when you first launch the game. It's basically just the Origin game, so now I've got 2 versions The Sims 4 on Origin. The only benefit is Trading Cards and having the game on your Steam profile, also you can buy it for cheap on Sale, thanks GabeN. EA also could have at least given us achievements to at least show they care about the Steam platform, but no they didn't.. why? Because that'd require them to work with the Steamworks API, instead you can enjoy your worthless Origin achievements.. :(

Ignore the playtime. I've got probably over a thousand hours logged, and most of the expansion content. I don't mind that they make a lot of packs. I think that's actually nice because it provides a way to feasibly expand content regulardly. However, I do take exception to a lot of other decisions the company makes. Below are just a few. First, using a pre-existing game to move to free-to-play was not a considerate move for the current player base. This was something I sorta saw coming for a while when they started introducing Kits. In fact, in Sims 1, I discovered the team had been looking into microtransactions for the sims other than full EPs. This is likely just the beginning of such a transition, and the quality will likely decrease over time as a result. Second, even with full EPs in existence, the team often released content patches that didn't undergo enough testing and wind up breaking a different paid expansion. Just a few months ago, I discovered that one of the features in the Get to Work pack was broken and had been for months, I just hadn't used it. This isn't an issue that requires mods to reproduce either. Third, the consideration at large for the player base seems to be non existent. The Build Your Own Bundle has been unavailable for over three months for several of the more recent packs, and the team has not made any public communications regarding this. They have no ETA for a fix, and this is not the first time this has occurred. There's been several times in the past where they simply did not include new packs for many many months. Their official stance in the past has always been "about a month". If it is in fact something they plan to fix, it needs to be better communicated to the player base. I really hope we see more competitors for the Sims franchise in the future, because its uniqueness seems to be its primary draw.

its a really great game but the packs are really expensive.The exstension packs are about 30 or 40,the game packs are 20(i think) and the stuff packs are 10 and the game is 40 so if you buy the game + an extension pack its 70 or 80 so its pretty expensive but i'll still recommend this game.The building in this game is really great,i've seen some really great stuff in the gallery but its definitely not easy,it took me about 4-5 hours to build the first floor and my garden(but its probs just me).The gameplay is definatly one of the best gameplays i've played/seen.Though it might be a little annoying when you have a big family and they need a lot of stuff.But its definitely not impossible.Since i got the cats and dogs pack i'll review it too.It's definitely a really great pack and if you want a extension pack then i'll highly recommend this pack since you get to customize the cats and dogs with paint mode and the clothes are really cute/nice for the animals.You also get 338 Build mode items.The clothes/items in cas(create a sim) are kinda good but i'll recommend getting cc(custom content) to make your sims better(not saying the clothes are terrible but it will just look better with cc).Welp that was my whole review on the sims 4 so i hoped it helped ^^.

I've played the previous two sims games. The Sims 4 is an improvement on previous games in that the Sims can have different walks and their aspirations can change. You can travel with your Sims to work and this opens a new world. It is, however, a downgrade from Sims 3. The game isn't open world like Sims 3 and information isn't readily available. Your Sims can travel by using the phone, whereas you could previously walk, ride a bicycle or drive to your destination, in Sim 3. Things like grocery and book stores aren't readily available in the map. Which means you can either pay for items as you make them or try grow the ingredients yourself. CAS is quite limited. The colours available for outfits are set so you won't be able to amek/save any custom colours that look better on your Sim. This also applies to the furniture and decorations such as rugs. The game is still addictive, but I find myself comparing Sims 4 to Sims 3 quite often during gameplay. The improvements made in Sims 4 do not outweigh the setbacks in Sims 4.

A big step backwards from Sims 3. I really wanted to like this... I put hundreds of hours into S3. But unlike that, which had an open world, dynamic - evolving in the background, that made you feel you were in a living breathing world. This is just a small plot of land, closed off from the world, everything closed off behind loading screens like the original Sims. Yes - graphics are lovely, though too cartoonish for my tastes, and yes their emotions and multi tasking are more fleshed out, and definitely an improvement... But I just can't get over the big step down in content and simulation feel from S3. And the piles of DLC that cost 28 bucks on sale, 40 retail...?! I just can't, not for a base game this inferior to it's predecessor... I'm going to have to hold out for Sims 5... But if EA behaves the same... I'm starting to lose hope in the franchise...

I bought this game because I liked the Sims 2 and 3. But this game looks and feels like a slightly changed Sims 3, with a lot more bugs. There are not really any new things, only changed gameplay of existing ideas. The bugs are sometimes really annoying, when a Sim cannot use doors after every shower, NPCs randomly explode to 30 bananas or Sims have to sit down 3 times before they can interact again. I got the game in Steam Sale with -50%, and it still feels overpriced. The DLC prices are just crazy: The full game with all functionality would cost 520 Euros during the -50% Sale!

If you're buying this game on steam to avoid Origin, then you're out of luck.  Steam just adds an extra layer of DRM and requires you to download and open origin to run the game.  It's also got less features than the Sims 3 unfortunately, so really it just comes down to slightly better graphics.  I'll play it, but I can't recommend it.

The game is so blatantly devoid of content without DLC, which costs over ¬£1000 full price ¬£555(gbp) at the minute. Feels like a mobile game compared to Sims 3. Seems to have some fun aspects though - CAS and Build modes are much better and more varied, if with slightly less customisation. I can't recommend the game due to lack of content and simply because my preference is Sims 3. You might enjoy it if you're less focused on the actual gameplay and want to build/create sims. It's also nice to have some quality of life updates that aren't in sims 3, like scaled UI and generally the game feels cleaner. But, like I said, it's obvious even from the get-go that there is hardly any content. I'd recommend Sims 3, even without mods or custom content.

This is still not as good as The Sims 3, it's lacking so many features like the open world and create a style. I did a literal face palm when I saw the price of all the dlc's on the steam store, over $1400 to get a lot of things that used to be much cheaper in previous games. They split older expansions up into new more expensive expansions like Supernatural, it's now 4 different expansions which costs $135 to get the same amount of content as before. The neighborhoods are much smaller, with only 4 or 5 lots per map, it feels like a huge downgrade all the way back to The Sims 1 again. I honestly can't recommend this game for this price, there is no good way to buy this game, not even the Deluxe edition comes bundled with any dlc's. It would of been nice to get a more complete package for $60 especially 8 years later... The only positive thing I can say about it is that it's nice all the custom content is in game now, much like the browser from Spore, it's great to be able to just plop down a custom sim or lot without having to download and copy over files. But it doesn't add much to the game with everything that got taken away.

While more streamlined and easier to play, I still feel like I'm babysitting Sims instead of looking at the Big Picture. Due to DLC, I cannot recommend. However, the base game is playable in itself.

I love the game and have played it considerably longer than thankfully Steam has listed here. That being said, unmodded the game is not worth playing. I have over 70 bug fixes installed that address stuff that isn't working correctly and overhaul mechanics that make no sense. You can't even have your Sims cook a meal and eat it together without a mod. You don't want them to drink 600 glasses of water a day? You'll need a mod to fix it.  Don't want them to die of boredom, laughter, or other weird stuff? MCCC fixes it. You want them to walk like normal people? You need another mod. Of course, with every expansion you add, the list of mods required to make the game playable grows longer. If you decide to buy it anyway, do yourself a favour and download MCCC right away. Then head over to LittleMsSam's site and download her numerous gameplay fixes and for realistic gameplay check Zero's stuff.

I've been a long time Sims fan, I remember playing one of them on my DS as a kid and begging to buy Sims 3 pets. Straight up, Sims 3 was way better than this. If you're going to buy Sims, get Sims 3 and don't waste all your money on this. I can't remember all the negatives about this game so I'll have to come back to update this review at some point. Pros: - The newest version of Sims and is getting updates and new content released - Sims are more emotive(?) - More customisation with a Sims body with a click and drag style. - Better graphics/smoother. This may be due to the lack of open world/free-roaming but that's also a con. - Mermaids look better in the 'Island living' DLC Cons: - Too many DLCs, most are quick cash grabs. They're expensive and useless, adding little to nothing to the base game. I can bet that a good chunk of comments one any new DLC release post is just people booing and mouthing off at the developers. You can't control yours pets in the pets DLC, there's no horses there either (I miss unicorns). The Supernatural DLCs (yes there's more than one if you want the full Sims 4 supernatural experience) has significantly less content than the one from Sims 3. Why are there around three DLCs for life stages (child, teen and young adult) ? I feel that a lot of DLCs could have been combined or been worked on more. It all feels half done. - Less personality traits. It's so bare. - No open world/free-roaming, travelling between lots is annoying. This means no cars and bikes too. - Custom colours/colour wheel and textures were removed in create a sim. - Mods are required just to make the game better (thank the community for that) - Whims are a little messed up. You can't 'cancel' them, only pin. I know I compare Sims 4 to Sims 3 a lot but it's really telling when the previous game was better than the current one. Sims 5 better exceed the lower expectations that the community have.

I want to start this by saying I grew up with both of these games (at around the same time), so they hold the same sentimental value to me and I am not trying to be biased, rather proving how much different EA has become when caring about their games and using more paywalls. I started by playing the Sims 3 as I couldn‚Äôt find the Sims 4 on Steam (I was young, and was willing to take any sort of Sims game as I was excited to play). After playing it for many hours, I bought the Sims 4. For both of them, I bought a few packs (with the game): Sims 3: seasons, generations, pets. | Sims 4: cats and dogs, parenthood, seasons Playing the Sims 3 with three packs was enough for hundreds of hours of content. Buying the supernatural pack had just as much content as one of the other packs and was much more than sufficient to play many games. Playing the Sims 4, however, felt much different. Playing the Sims 4 with three packs (which were worth the game at the time) felt like a whole bunch of nothing. It was missing the fun, the goofiness, and the soul that the Sims 3 had. The Sims 3 had much more, even when it came down to small gameplay mechanics. Cars, grocery shopping, visible schools and other public places, functional and lively parks, enjoyable holidays, lively cities, traits that implemented interesting gameplay mechanics, interesting moodlets, imaginary friends, backyard entertainment (such as treehouses), and much much more that I don‚Äôt think I have enough characters to write down. For the Sims 4, much of that needs mods or other game packs, and both options don‚Äôt even work half of the time. Even the Sims 3‚Äôs soundtrack sounds much more lively, leaving room for the player to think about how and what part of the game they want to discover and enjoy. I‚Äôm not saying the Sims 4‚Äôs soundtrack isn‚Äôt good, as I feel Ilan Eshkeri captured some of the franchise‚Äôs essence, however, it still feels much more like a paywall or just a huge loading screen rather than music for a game such as the Sims. It isn‚Äôt as lively, and not all of the DLC music fits together. Like Vampires - I understand it is supposed to be seen as creepy, but the gameplay should be focusing more on that aspect, not the music. The Sims 3 Supernatural didn‚Äôt add more ‚Äòcreepy‚Äô music, instead, it found that vibe in the gameplay. The scariest thing about the Sims 4 Vampires Pack is the music and terrible clothing/hair/facial customizable options for your sims, whilst Supernatural delves deeper into the gameplay and feels more fleshed out. While it didn‚Äôt bring as much creepy music, it did bring us the song Consuming Time which is just as good, and fits the vibe for the whole game itself. The music for the DLCs in the Sims 4 feels much more pack-based, rather than focusing on the whole game‚Äôs vibe itself, making the vibe of the whole game all over the place, and scrambled. It had more use when it came to knowing the phases of the moon, researching vampires, PLAYING as vampires, or any of the other options that the DLC added (witches, wizards, werewolves, fairies). Each was unique, having much more interesting interactions than Vampires, Werewolves, and Realm of Magic combined. That is another thing I want to add is the fact that the Sims 4 has so many separated packs, when the Sims 3 had Werewolves, Realm of Magic, and Vampires combined, and did not cost as much as the game. The same thing goes for the Sims 3 Pets versus the Sims 4 Dogs and Cats, My First Pet Stuff, and Horse Ranch. Sims 3 Pets has all those options all in one DLC, less than the game, and actually works and has sufficient content (all three of those are missing one or the other, Dogs and Cats and My First Pet Stuff being boring/a whole lot of nothing while Horse Ranch is literally just broken). The fact that many of the packs can still cost up to 50 dollars for broken, separated gameplay with only one of the advertised products in the game is so disappointing. I understand the Sims 3 used to be 40 dollars, but it also has so much more to offer compared to the Sims 4, even in base-game. It‚Äôs actually playable by itself. Although the Sims 4 is now free, I still wouldn‚Äôt recommend it to any first-time players. Yes, the Sims 3 is older and can have some problems (such as glitching when you try to open it, having sensitivity problems), but it still is a much better starting place than the Sims 4. The only people who would want to play the Sims 4 either don‚Äôt know how boring the game is unless you buy hundreds of dollars worth of DLCs or are seasoned players hoping that someday this game will be good. I have spent well over 500 dollars into this game and it still isn‚Äôt playable. Playing thousands of hours of the Sims 3 and then finally saving up enough to buy this one was such a disappointment. The DLCs for the Sims used to add so much and certainly weren‚Äôt the same as the game itself. EA has done this sort of thing recently, whether it be with the Sims, Fortnite, Madden, FIFA, etc (in which I have had experience with all games listed) have had some sort of microtransactions. The games often feel incomplete (or versions of the game, in cases such as Fortnite) and are either missing the ‚Äòpizzazz‚Äô so to speak of the last game or have become unenjoyable. For a seven-year-old game, you would expect the DLCs to be enjoyable, and actually add stuff to the game, and work half the time. But even the newest releases have problems, such as; Party Essentials Kit, For Rent, Wedding Stories, Dream Home Decorater, Backyard Stuff, Vintage Glamour, Bowling Night, ect ect (some of those aren‚Äôt new, but you get my point, only half of them work, and most of them add like two items to the game). I understand most of the packs listed are only around 5 dollars, but why even make them that much? Why can‚Äôt you just add them to the game to begin with, making it a little bit more enjoyable and worth anything? It has been very hard for me to get even an hour out of this game at a time, and trying to squeeze out as much content as this game offers has proven difficult and frustrating. I had to actively work to find stuff to do in this version, completely unlike the Sims 3. Even the pre-set households in the Sims 3 felt more interesting than anything in the Sims 4. I tried building cities, families, and storylines in the Sims 4 and it just felt so forced. That is yet another problem with EA and the Sims franchise recently; EA only cares about the money they receive from this game, and does not care about the quality of the products they are selling for it. All the DLCs for this game add up to over 1,000 dollars. Half of them don‚Äôt work. It is upsetting to see a game franchise devolve in quality and have the creators only care about the profit. If EA actually cared for this game, listened to even half of the critics, and fixed these problems it would make them so much more money. Who knew - that making an enjoyable game would appease players? Hopefully (yet unlikely), EA will turn this game around and make it more enjoyable like its predecessors, or make the next game in this series an improvement to the dumpster fire we have now. All in all, the Sims 3 (or even Sims 2, for that matter) is much more enjoyable, and I would consider spending my money on that game before spending any sort of time playing this one. It is so much more fleshed out and detailed in so many more ways and is overall just a better game. For a franchise so meaningful to people, with a record of being enjoyable for years on end from each installment, I am extremely disappointed in how this game has turned out.

I love the Sims and have many good memories of playing it. Before I had my own Steam account, I constantly used my dad's PC to play the game. However, I can see how nostalgia blinded me to liking the Sims 4 over time. It lacks innovation or creativity, details are choppy, and you will play for an hour or so until you quit. First of all, the need for more innovation and creativity is apparent. It quickly shows in how they force you to pay for simple aspects of life such as weather, animals, and even weddings (now, at least, lol). Even when allowed to make DLC add depth to aspects, it shows it is a complete cash grab. From every bug and error they refuse to fix to the simple concepts they add to the game and charge $40, it shows the Sims 4 is draining money. When I first saw they added seasons as an expansion pack instead of a game update, oh my word, I lost my mind. They charge you $40 for seasons and weather, then call it a day. Don't even get me STARTED on the crappy details. Can we address how ugly the Sims look base game? They give you JACK to work with and then pride themselves in it. There must be more POC-friendly makeup and hairstyles, BASIC ASPECTS OF LIFE. Has EA ever heard of 4C hair? Ooh, it's the scary ghost of putting effort into hair, clothing, makeup, and skin details. It's not like they like the money to add detail to these things. I could write an entirely separate essay on how infuriated the hands and feet make me, but I won't. I love custom content creators because THEY are the gods and goddesses carrying this game. If I had the money to give them to make Sims 4 but better, I would. The gameplay is so dull after a while, making you laugh and then cry a little. You click "Get to know," "Flirt," "Marry," and then you mass-produce a family. They go to work, eat for 50 hours, refuse to listen to you, and then die because they didn't. There is nothing to explore inside the world except for the park. Because I don't think people want to use the gym. People want to see places they go to daily and explore those environments. Things like going to the grocery store, DRIVING THEIR CARS, gas stations, random small businesses, workplaces, and schools. Some of these can be refuted with, "B-but... buy the DLC." The DLC that gives you three jobs and the ability to own a small business? How about the DLC that makes all the jobs playable and the ability to own, visit, and sell your small business? What should DLC be? Exploring obscure and exciting topics that aren't real or add depth to issues. How about the new wedding DLC? For example, you have to meet your parents. What if there were objections to the wedding or a runaway bride? What if the  DLC worked and didn't take 40 hours or longer to use? DLC should be focusing on adding to already in-depth topics. I need clarification on why you must pay to use critical aspects of life. The only DLC I understand is the magical ones because that is not real. EA knows we will buy the garbage expansion packs, so they make them. If there were a lack of profit from the Sims 4, more effort could be put into it. I'm not sure that would happen, considering they could quickly drop the franchise and abort the ship. Dropping the franchise would anger many people and spark further outrage with the game. In conclusion, this is a definite EA moment. I still play with my custom content and lack of a real-life; the only aspects that make it enjoyable. Just play IMVU or something.

First off I love The Sims series been a fan since I was child like many others. I've put many hours into The Sims 4 on origin. I've had this game since launch. There's something about this game that's not fun and it's been like that since launch. Even with all the DLC I still feel like there's something missing fundamentally. Sims in this game feel so hollow, no personality and no sense of progression. Gameplay is also imo really lacking most of the time playing is spent at your lot because of all the loading screens you have to go through. So many missing features as well compared to older titles like come on it doesn't even have burglars which have always been in the game there‚Äôs no grit and realism. One thing this game does right is the Build/Buy and CAS mode and small things like multitasking, It's fantastic and the graphics are great compared to its predecessors. The Sims 4 really reminds me of a Bethesda title game where it's up to the modders to make it better. The support from the community is insane with all the CC available. When you compare it to The Sims 3 sims felt alive and the world around them did also. Could it be the lack of an open world? the lack of a deep trait/personality system? I really encourage Sims 4 only players to give Sims 3 BASE a chance just so you can see the difference in terms of gameplay. I hope ‚ÄúMaxis‚Äù can really improve on the next Sims entry. Go back to and see what made The Sims 1-3 so great. TL;DR Salty Sims 3 player complains about Sims 4 for the 1000000th time

Made character named The Devil. Was doing gardening for profit and crime as hobby (it was her work, but with how much it was paying compared to doing garden, it was more of a hobby). Garden became too big for one person to work in it. Found some black guy that was living next door, moved in with him, sent him to my plantations (have tried hiring professional gardener, but she was coming to only water plants once in couple of days, even if schedule was showing it more often). I do not own Sims 4 on Steam (did try it on free weekend), but I have it in Origin, compared to Origin's version, it actually has English language (while my Origin gives me choice between Czech, Polish and Russian and I have no wish to play it in any of those languages). If you own both Steam and Origin version, when you open game with Steam, it still opens up your Origin and makes 2 different Sims in it (one has tag Steam to it and other one doesn't). DLC to Sims 4 cost a fortune, but without it you're not gonna play it for long. From nice things that you get with base game that I do not remember having in Sims 2 is multitasking for some of the things (can do toilet with phone together or talk to someone while gardening) and mobile phone (so you don't have to buy stationary phone, you don't have to run to it every time you need something from it). You can redeem Potions of Youth from completing milestones in different aspirations, so your sim doesn't age. However it fast became repetitive, house building is somewhat scuffed, I barely did anything other than levelling two skills to 10 and doing whatever I have described above and I'm already too bored to come back to it.

The game is great, if you can run it. I bought this game years ago on Origin, and the Origin game launcher client is very poor. Today, when I installed the game via steam, I had hoped to finally be able to play this game without the origin launcher and its incredible annoying problems. But alas, no. Steam launched the origin client, which demanded that I log in, and when I did, it started updating Sims 4, but then reported the launcher was down for maintenance, and then put me in a forever loop where it demanded that I try to go online, which immediately kicked me offline again and again. I had to kill the launcher via the task manager. Eventually, some time later, I tried again, and origin again required me to type in all my credentials, then tried to update sims 4, but ran into some other problem and refused to update sims 4. I then killed origin launcher again. I waited a bit longer, and tried again. THIS time, when origin asked for admin access to update stuff, I said no. Origin then prompted again and again for admin access. I denied it a good 30 to 50 times before it finally gave up. I stopped the sims 4 failed update, and I finally got into sims 4. Origin kept prompting me again and again for admin access, and I'm now looking for a way to prevent the buggy origin launcher from ever being on my computer again. Go to hell origin launcher. Leave me alone. Damn buggy launcher. I regret every game I've ever bought from origin because I can't play them due to their stupid launcher.

I finally purchased it last month on a discount to give it a try. It was so bad I just went back to The Sims 2 and The Sims 3. Now I have clocked 200+ hours in a month just on The Sims 3. I don't deny that the build tool in The Sims 4 is amazing. But the rest of the game was meh. The Sims 4 feels like a real dollhouse instead of life simulator. Even every sim is also looks like a doll. It is a total dumbed-down version of The Sims series. It is just because the greedy EA wanted to make The Sims more mainstream so they can milk the money even more. So they ditched many features from The Sims 3 to make The Sims 4 runnable in a low-spec computer. They knew that even a high-end computer struggled so bad when running the feature-complete The Sims 3. So their conclusion was: do not make a highly ambitious game like The Sims 3 anymore. Did you all know that even The Sims 4 was released in 32-bit only in 2014 and created a backlash in the community. The reasoning is no other than to allow older and lower spec PC to run the game, thus wider market segment, and MOAR MONEY. Did you all also know that The Sims 4 was exclusively on Origin too until this year? At first they want to escalate their Origin services. But now the market there is already saturated, and many people won't migrate or install Origin. So, they decided to put it on Steam shelves too, to increase the market again, and MOAR MONEY again! Glad I only spend $20 for TS4+Season bundle. I considered to give it a chance but, no. I am not going to spend any more pennies to this game. You all should not too. Let EA dies with their greediness.

For as long as I've played TS4, almost every update has introduced subtle, major, or even game-breaking glitches. The patches to fix these glitches only add more glitches. The quality control is abysmal, and so are the greedy ambitions to chuck out empty DLC at ridiculously inflated prices. EA is killing the Sims franchise, and their past actions and future plans are proof of that. If you want a fulfilling Sims experience, play The Sims 3. Unlike TS4, that game isn't free... but also, unlike TS4, it's actually worth it.

As a Sims 3 fan, I went into The Sims 4 very skeptical. Took a bit longer than I'd expected, but eventually I got into it and I've since grown to LOVE The Sims 4. It misses quite a lot of details, and in many ways it has less "soul" than previous entries, but The Sims 4 has grown into a game that, in my opinion, stands on its own. The art style is easy on the eyes, and the "cartooniness" adds a lot of character to the sims themselves. The soundtrack, though a bit boring at times, compliments the gameplay by providing simple background noise. It can be a bit buggy, but I've noticed nothing game breaking so far. The emotions provide extra depth to your sims and not only the interactions they have with other sims, but how they interact with objects as well. There's also a huge plethora of skills I did not anticipate, including but not limited to Charisma, Comedy, Flower Arranging, Mixology, Cooking, Gourmet Cooking, Programming, Photography, Video Gaming, Singing, and many more. Most of my complaints revolve around the lack of options for cosmetics without DLC, especially compared to the "create a style" feature in The Sims 3, which allowed you to select patterns and change the exact colors of every piece of clothing (as well as hair and makeup) using a color wheel, hex numbers, and RBG values. This allowed for a much deeper and rewarding create-a-sim. I always enjoyed taking specific sims and giving them a color theme, that most of the outfits were built around so they felt more unique. This is severely limited in The Sims 4. Lastly, there are the DLC packs. Plenty of them are good, some are REALLY good, and some are... disappointing. Overall I dont suggest buying this unless its on sale, but that especially applies to the DLC. Though I can particularly recommend Get to Work, Seasons, Get Famous, Parenthood, and Vampires. Lots of fun additions in those. Overall I recommend The Sims 4, and have definitely gotten my money's worth out of it.

You can barely even make anything interesting. It seems fun in concept, that's why I tried really hard to like it. But quite frankly the way EA monetises these games is just disgusting. DLC is fine as long as you don't pay wall literally everything. They don't understand this and don't care. Only thing that this game is good for for light spenders is a way to practice drawing furniture/rooms...

The Sims is such a great concept. As a child I would sit in my dad's lap and watch him play the Sims 1 and 2, and I've poured hundreds of hours into 3 and 4 over the years. I can only imagine how great of a game the Sims 4 would be if EA didn't lock content like: high-school, college, interactive careers, pets, seasons, weather etc. behind a $40 paywall each. It is disgusting. Most of the aforementioned content should be included in the base game. I don't hate the idea of paid-for DLC, but greedy developers like EA will make half of a game and release the other half gradually over the years in the form of outrageously priced expansions. $5.00 is far more reasonable for the various expansions for this game, but EA understands there are enough prats out there to burn nearly $1000.00 on this exorbitant trash.

I don't pirate games anymore, but this for real could be the only game I would get from torrents. The reason is, of course, the extremely overpriced DLCs. Things like having a pet dog or a cat is for some reason a DLC. And it costs 40 freaking euros. And there are many DLC's like that. Some minor clothes packs which add a 30 or so items cost 20 euros. If you want the full game experience, it's in total more than 600 euros, I think. I can't support companies like that no way. DLC's are ok, just as long as they add something novel not expected in the base game. Pets have been in the Sims since the first game and is nothing new.

Get the Sims 3...its not worth it. The Sims 4 is certainly enjoyable, but its a money pit that just doesn't do things as well as the previous Sims game.  You get less content for your money, you can tell alot is missing from the game which they sequestered off unless you decide to pay $10-20$+ for it all.  Like, there are building feature tabs with no items in them...clearly those items were made, but they purposefully left them out because they wanted more money.  I'm fine with that all to an extent, but to purposefully provide less content in your vanilla version so you can milk it is vastly different than releasing a finished product and THEN adding content to it to spice things up.  So whereas the base game is really cheap, a good portion of the DLC/contentpacks should have been in the base game, but were purposefully left out. But going to pros and cons- Pros: -Finding items on the world map is more exciting -Alot of restrictions that were more politically correct and limited character growth were removed -More customization/options to do various tasks than the previous Sims -Character interactions and graphics were updated and look really nice Cons: -Unlike previous Sims, they added content after Vanilla was released as icing; this game seems to have been made and content was removed where you will need to buy that removed content (what my mini-rant above was about) -Certain features are not implemented well, like finding items in the world.  Having certain items always appear at certain places consistently every few days cheapens the action -Its way too easy...if you start out with the normal 20k, start the game with $30 in your pocket and plan to slowly add to your interiors as you slowly get promoted, you don't do that anymore.  You start off with the 20k on a house, spend it till you get $30 and then you walk outside and scavenge to get an easy 1k every few days.  Before you know it, you never need to actually work to just have unlimited funds.  This makes alot of game choices and options seem very trivial -The new simplified SIMs emotion bar is incredibly easy, and it slowly loses its appeal.  You CAN change this in the options menu to the old SIMs emotion bar, but it leaves the same impression as if you found a way to cheat in the game.  Its hard to go back because the cheats make everything easier, but now that everything is easier, there doesn't seem to be much motive to do anything.  This should not be the default emotion bar, the more complicated SIMs emotion bars should be default. -Interactions are more boring...unless you buy the content flavor packs, its kind of like Crusader Kings...after 10 hours you kind of lose your motivation.  There aren't enough random events or things to do. Overall: It might be worth it to buy it ONLY on sale, but you'll need to get all of the content and flavor packs.  The DLCs are also just too small in of themselves...its like they took the Sims3 (which already had issues with spending money on lots of dlcs and content packs), somehow made it even more about money by giving you less for the same.   Effectively, you are getting a graphics upgrade for a few new minor features that aren't implemented well.  Stick to the Sims3, or better yet, the Sims2 and you'll never even care about whats going on with this new one.  Also, they plan to release the Sims5 soon so...why spend $150 dollars on this when you can wait to see about the new one (which I assume is a clone of Sims 3 & 4, just with a slightly different flavor of icing on it).

Not recommended to players unwilling to give EA hundreds of dollars, as more than 90% of the game is locked behind paywalls and the base game is basically unplayable without mods. I'd only recommend the game if you're willing and able to download enough mods to make it feel like a full game instead of a free demo, which is what I've done at the expense of my poor storage drive.

Wasted potential - wasted cash The Sims 4 is the worst game in the core Sims-franchise to date. Being a major step-down from its predecessors and having base content stripped in favor of DLC's. The Sims DLC policy has always been horrid, but the Sims 4 brings it at a whole new low with many of the DLC's, which some might consider essential, costing the same as the base game itself. Even when buying these various expansions on sale, you're still looking at hundreds of Euros wasted. If you are looking into the Sims-franchise, look into the earlier installments of the series. The Sims, the Sims 2 and the Sims 3 are all excellent, less costly and by far more enjoyable, and the only real difference between the Sims 3 and Sims 4 is the jump in graphics and the abolishing of the open world aspect which many liked in the Sims 3. The Sims 4 is the embodiment of modern EA's atrocious policies. Regardless, as the base game of the Sims 4 is often on sale for a fiver, getting it isn't a huge dent in most people's personal economies. So get it, try it out and make your own mind, but for the love of God don't give EA 500 Euros for the DLC's, or we will see the Sims 5 with DLC that cost twice the base game.

Game is fun enough, when it works. My experience has been relatively stable, playing un-modded, but I've also avoided the DLCs with the worst reputations. I give the game a thumbs down mostly to serve as a warning to people: the game's DLC structure and pricing is very predatory and absolutely harms the quality of the game. Life progression things like seasons, college, and weddings are tied to paid packs, and numerous small gameplay elements that were formerly included in base versions of the game have been locked away behind additional purchases. If you have the cash to burn and are interested in the game, then absolutely dive in. Just be aware of what you are getting into. I give a negative review while freely admitting that I will likely end up with several hundred hours of gameplay. But, EA has overall been rather scummy in their approach to The Sims 4, so don't expect a perfectly smooth experience through blissfully calm waters. You'll end up paying a lot of money for what can sometimes be a bit of a sloppy mess. But when it works, it really works.

Sims 2 and 3 are far better. Sims 4 lacks day to day events leading to things becoming quite boring. For example, in previous games, things could catch on fire or you could have a thief attempt to steal stuff. You could have alien encounters and a bunch of other kooky stuff happen. All I've seen in sims 4 is that the sink bursts and you have to fix it, or you get a text from someone asking for relationship advice. Additionally, the expansion packs are very expensive for cosmetic additions and don't seem to be worth the money. Building is also a lot clunkier than sims 2 and 3 making building less fun. Really disappointing. I would advise getting sims 2 or 3 for a decent experience.
