I would enjoy this game substantially more if EA didn't manage to perfect the art of price-gouging you for half-baked "expansions" and "stuff packs" that don't even come close to justifying the cost, let alone add much to the game itself. I was an OG Sims 1 player from the start and have gone through each successive generation over the last 20 years. The Sims 1 and 2 brought a LOT of new stuff to the table with their expansion packs that justified the cost enough to be well worth it. Instead of a paltry amount of items and some "new" features, they were robust, contained a TON of new items, a lot of new activities, and overall just felt like fully formed product. The Sims 4 in particular has managed to water down its DLC to a point where you're basically paying $20 for a handful of things you care about, or to find out you literally have zero interest in what the pack ultimately contains. Simply put? EA has monetized every damn sock, shoe, blade of grass, and function in this game to a point where it's well past blatant greed. It is NOT worth the total cost of all these packs, and it seems every new addition is just more garbage dumped on a few interesting items/features to fluff it up artificially and make it look like it's actually bringing something new to the table. It's not. Half these expansion packs are DLC that either used to be a part of the base game in previous iterations, or would have previously been a part of a much larger DLC that actually justified the cost. It's unbelievably disappointing to come back to this game after a near-decade hiatus only to find it has deteriorated so heavily under the EA Overlords. To make matters worse, the UI itself is A T R O C I O U S. This thing is literally missing features that were previously a part of the predecessors' UI that were arguably integral to the functionality of the game. The Sims 4 is clunky, annoying to work with, and missing some basic-ass features like holding ctrl down to delete a floor tile, or being able to just place a floor tile. WHY IS THIS NOT A FEATURE? You literally have to build a closed room around it just to get it to fill with a piece of tile, and what is beyond infuriating about this is if you say, move a stairway trying to find the right spot for it between two levels, have fun having to mess with your floor BS all over again. Then there's issues like holding ctrl down to paint an entire room with the same wall texture. Does it work like that anymore? No, of course not, why would we not break something that was working great before?! Nope now it seems to be locked to the chunk of wall you put in, so if you wind up editing a room's shape or piecing it together as  you go, you now have to manually paint the walls and if you hold ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• down, it'll fill a CHUNK of SOME wall tiles that may or may not even be in that room. I just cannot for the life of me understand how a game that has been around for 20 years and had a pretty damn good UI and functionality in the Sims 2 (which in many ways, I'd say they nearly perfected, as it was simple, intuitive, and straight forward but allowed a huge amount of freedom), all for the Sims 4 to just.... act like it's never seen a Sims game before??? Great. The ONE FEATURE the base game DID bring to the table that I absolutely love is the ability to save/move/rotate/edit the walls of/ an entire room. Being able to copy and save these to your library is a true game-changer, and being able to poke around at these things certainly has a huge benefit as you build. Unfortunately this seems to be one of the only things I can compliment this game on after a couple hundred hours of gameplay. Thank god for mods, man. Granted, mods have always been the heart and soul of this game, but it would be nice for the game to also feel like EA is doing everything they can to drain my wallet just so I can have things that quite frankly don't even have enough to BE reasonable DLC. Unless you're a die-hard enthusiast with a crapload of cash to burn, beware: this game costs a stupid amount of money to get the content for and it is NOT worth the total cost.

Ugh. This is so hard to review for me. I've been a Sims lover for a long, long time. I started playing 2, then 3, then 4. I have probably 2k hours in the Sims 4 on Origin. Most people would probably say 2 is the best, but I think it's 3. There is just so much story and so much to do in 3, not to mention the open world was amazing. Now in 4, we have....not much. Every pack we have gotten that was in a previous Sims game, sucked. Pets in 3 included horses and tons of small animals. 4 we only got cats and dogs. The improvements they made on CAS and house building are phenomenal, I'll give them that. But, how am I supposed to enjoy those things when I feel like I have nothing to use? CAS is ok, I don't use it too much so I'm fine with the stuff that's in there. Build/buy mode is a different story. I feel like I'm stuck using the same 3 rugs because they're the only ones that have swatches I like. Did I mention that the Sims 4 doesn't have a colour wheel? It sucks when you figure that out after playing 3 for so long. I just feel like the Sims 4 developers don't care about us. There have been SO many reported bugs that just either a) never get fixed or b) get fixed way way later. They only care about making new packs, and their latest "invention", kits. Kits. Are. The. Worst. I'm SO SO sick of seeing every single month "hey guys new kit!" They came out with that wedding pack pretty recently and IT IS SO BAD!!!!!!!! How are they just getting away with releasing a broken, unfinished pack? I have no idea, but it's very apparent that they do not care about us. EA stinks.

Say whatever you want about it. Yes, there are annoying fake buildings everywhere that your Sim cannot enter. Yes, you have to wait through a loading screen if you want to visit a neighbour next door. Yes, there are tons of small DLCs. Yes, there are no cars. Yes, the towns are so small that it somewhat justifies the lack of cars (you simply don't need transport, there is a Bicycle if you really want it). And yes, there is "My First Pet Stuff". However, there is just so much more in terms of building houses, creating a Sim, general stabilty of the game (I am yet to experience a game crash or a significant bug), perfomance (stable above 60 FPS with full max settings), superfast loading times, overall contemporary vibe of the game... That there is simply no comeback to Sims 3 for me, despite having several hundred hours spent there years ago. I still love Sims 3, don't get me wrong, but sometimes good things should remain where they belong - in good memories. And here's hoping that Sims 5 will satisfy everyone.

Every bit as bad as they say. Only took me an hour to come to the conclusion that Sims 4 is an EA standard joke. That's an all time record for me. Character creation was already making me cringe. By the time I got past the insultingly limited customization options and horrendous interface, I was gazing upon the neighborhood map. I almost vomited. Previous sims games prided themselves on their big detailed neighborhood maps with tons of lots you can place any building on. Everything constructed and placed from the ground up if you want to. You could even ad purely visual flairs to your neighborhood like additional streets, tree coverage, radio towers, hot air balloons, beachheads and lighthouses. Sims 4 "neighborhood" is one screen with twelve lots illustrated with basic shapes. Literally the only option is to choose a lot. So once my Sims are on their vacant lot I find that there are no pre built houses apparently? The interface is so gobsmackingly terrible I couldn't figure out if there are. So apparently houses are assembled from a selection of prebuilt furnished rooms now. You just cobble them together to make your house. I don't @#$%ing believe it! This is what The Sims architectural simulation has been reduced to? Smashing prefab rooms together? Oh sure, you can add outlines for walls and stuff but, by God, is this interface terrible and aggressively limited in functionality. For some reason my dining room didn't care to put an entry to my kitchen. When I spent 10 minutes trying to figure out where the front flipping @#$% they hid the doors and windows I finally quit. Knowing that the Sims 4 and all of its numerous insanely overpriced expansions are all stripped down from previous entries I honestly don't care enough to fuss with this absolute joke of a Sims game for any longer than an hour. That's all of the time I'm giving to the clowns at EA. I picked up Sims 3 alongside 4 through EA's subscription thing so I could try Sims 4 on a lark just to see for myself what a pathetic joke it is. As soon as I started up Sims 3 I was immediately inundated with more options and greater functionality than the Sims 2 offered. To load Sims 4 and be met with less than a tenth of what any of its predecessors offer in terms of content and functionality is just ludacris. Stay classy EA. The Sims themselves also look stupid af. The Sims used to have an endearing visual style to them. Now they look like something out of a creature show. People. The Sims, Sims 2, and Sims 3 all exist. Nobody has any business giving Sims 4 the time of day.

Love this series, probably always will since the 1st one. Unfortunately, they feel as though we should pay for everything they've created before again and again and again. So I'm guessing Pets is exactly the same stuff as 3 and 2, just updated graphics.  I like the additional skill leveling you can do in this one, so you can eat/drink coffee and watch TV at the same time or drink a glass of water and read at the same time, etc... They have definitely improved some of the mechanics on this go around but paying almost $600 for all the content you've probably already bought for 3 and 2 and maybe even the original just isn't worth it to me, even @ 30% off.  I'll just have to wait until they do one of those 75% off sales and get a couple more packs and hope that gets me by until the next one. One of the reasons I loved this series was because of the value but EA seized on that love we all have for it and charge you over and over and over again for the same stuff.  They don't really even change the names from year to year anymore. Such a shame Maxis went with EA.

Man, I love the Sims, I grew up playing it - starting with Sims 2 then transitioning to 3 and here I am playing 4 now. The series have provided me with countless hours of fun, but unfortunately, I have to say that this is the worst game that the franchise has to offer, not only is the gameplay very limiting without the Packs, but most of Packs are very buggy, overpriced and provide minimal content. Compare Sims 4 Packs with Sims 3 Packs for example. Sims 3's Packs offered much more content at a fairer price and you didn't even need them, the experience was complete by the base game alone. Also, in my opinion, the Sims 3's Packs are plain better not only in terms of content quantity, but quality too. The only good things that I can say about the Sims 4 is that in terms of building/character creation and graphics it's much superior than its predecessor, it even has multi-tasking, but that doesn't mean anything when the Packs are this minimalist, overpriced and buggy. If you really want to buy it I recommend you do at anything above 50% discount.

Although I bought this for 88% off I am very much underwhelmed. First the good. The building mechanics are pretty good, best I've seen in the Sims. Now the bad. The only added feature to game play from the Sims 3 is that sims can have moods (inspired, sad, flirty, etc.) and that can influence interactions and sim status (the color of the gem over their head). The customized style options for clothing, furniture and floors from the Sims 3 have been downgraded to pre-made options and no ability to actually make a custom color outfit (if you want a jacket in red but the jacket does not have red in it's pre-made swatches you're not getting it in red).  Sims' traits have been "simplified" to fit the new mood aspect of the game. Things to do in the game world are limited (there is a gym, a museum, a bar, and a park in every "world"). Interactions with other sims is weird, my characters apparently don't like to look at the person their talking to and my sim will just decide they don't want to do what I tell them to do. Overall, get the Sims 3, the expansion packs offer more content and exploring the neighborhood can actually be fun.

Update: 9-28-2024   I've been playing for quite some time now. I can't remember when I made my first review, but bugs fixes are only just happening, and I don't know if the bugs are getting fixed. Base game is still free, purchase packs on sale at your own risk. S4 is doing login rewards now..... Buyer beware! I enjoy playing the game, but I can't in good conscience recommend this game or any of it's DLCs because of all the bugs that still exist, even in the base game. On the plus side, base game is free, so I guess I can recommend installing the base game. There's a lot of little bugs that make the game borderline unbearable to play.... Build mode works fine, though, after you tweek the camera files to eliminate the camera drift in the Sims 3 camera mode. It took me 3 hours testing the code to get it just right..... So, I guess I can recommend base game for the build mode alone... With a lot of CC Mods.... And CAS is fun, too.

I'm a long time Sims fan (since 2002). I bought Sims 4 when it first came out and sold it in favor of staying with Sims 3. Recently, I've given Sims 4 another go, and I just have to say I was right the first time. Sims 4 is crazy buggy. Sims refusing to stay asleep, refusing to eat, not cooking (the command never even appears after I select which food), livestock disappearing at the fair, being stuck in place for hours at a time... The most mind blowing part is resetting a sim/object doesn't always work. Teleporting them doesn't always work. Canceling actions doesn't always work. I have no mods. This is straight vanilla. Even as a free game, it's not worth it. The expansions especially aren't worth it.

The Sims is a classic series offering endless fun and creativity to sparkle...at a steep cost. While the base title itself is cheap and fully playable, this is a horrid stripped down, cash grab title that EA continues to milk with no end in sight. Graphically pleasing and soundtrack, though less iconic than it's predecessors, still is enjoyable and distinguishable. Career paths are limited but nothing less than what was found in The Sims 1. You will be disappointed in the sheer lack of variation is items/appliances to purchase for your sims if you do not opt for DLC. Overall, while The Sims 4 is a great title, considering it's outlandish pricing for all DLC ($700+) for all with 'Expansions' such as simple Seasons will run you into the ground and pity should be had for any who have purchased more than two. Bottom line: Your entire stimulus check will not even cover all the DLC, this is really saying something...

The game is good, but it's a terrible sequel to the rest of the games. It's a downgrade in too many aspects to ignore from the third game in the series. It feels less dynamic and soul-less. Much of the life simulation aspect of the series is watered down here. It looks better, but it feels more cartoony and lifeless. I like that they've gotten more inclusive though. The building has never been better. The perfromance is also better in this game compared to the third one. Many fans point out that they like the downgrade from an open world becauset the Sims 3's perfromance was bad. The Sims 3 has bad performance because it's built to run on a single thread. If a modern Sims game, optimized for modern computers, was to release; performance would be a non-issue. The Sims 3 was ahead of its time with its open world. This game should have been an open world too, it would run fine, and it would be a vastly more dynamic and breathing game. Many of the expansions are the same as the expansions of the previous games. There are just way too many expansions. The expansions contain barely any content compared to the expansions of the Sims 3. It feels like a total rip off. There's some expansions I didn't even realize was expansions until I looked it up. The business model of this game is one of the worst ones in the entire gaming industry. The only reason to play this game over the Sims 3 is that it plays more smoothly performance-wise, or if you are in love with the new art-style. In every other aspect of the game, with the exception of "Build mode", the Sims 3 is vastly superior to this game. It honestly feels like this game's sequel.

Sims 4 is free, but it still feels like several major steps backwards compared to Sims 3. Conversations always seem to turn negative even with a good + charismatic sim. Pros: S4 has better character creation (but no sims3 create-a-style). It has faster loading times. Multi-tasking is a good addition.

This game is stupidly expensive. "But isn't the game free?" Yeah it's free in the same way that samplers of cheese at Sams are free. It's just enough to whet your appetite and get you primed and ready to buy whatever they're trying to sell you. Only instead of getting a full pack of the sampler cheese they're trying to sell you sampler size bits of the cheese at full cheese pack sizes. Sane people don't buy into this ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• because who willingly pays money for samplers? The same thing goes for this game. The game is free but it isn't a game, not really. It's a peek through a window into a shopping center. It's perfect looking pintrest photos of things you want but can't afford. Then when you get whatever you're pining for you realize you've been had. In any other game you could've gotten just as much content for 1/7th the price. The problem is that there aren't many other games like this. It's not ridiculous to say that The Sims series has a monopoly on sandbox life sims, and that's why they get away with selling you bite sized DLC packs or flavor packs for the same price as feature length games sometimes! Besides the ethical problems this game is littered with bugs and weird menu problems. I've had my entire created household be deleted twice in a row for no reason other than I got booted back to the menu for some update. Why can't I save character's? Why does it have to be the whole household? Why can't I save a household until I buy land? Why does the save household feature just not work at all sometimes? Don't get me wrong though this game is fun, really. It's just that getting to where you can have the maximum enjoyment you can out of it requires you to pour an obscene amount of money into EAs guts. If you really want to play it I'd recommend putting on your peg leg and eyepatch.

Introduction: "The Sims 4" offers players a vibrant and immersive simulation experience where creativity knows no bounds. From designing dream homes to shaping the lives of virtual characters, this game invites players into a world of endless possibilities. Graphics and Design: Visually, "The Sims 4" is stunning. The colorful and detailed graphics bring the world to life, whether you're exploring bustling neighborhoods or customizing your Sims' appearances. The intuitive design makes navigating menus and building structures a breeze, even for newcomers to the series. Gameplay and Features: The core gameplay of "The Sims 4" revolves around managing the lives of virtual characters known as Sims. Players can create unique Sims with distinct personalities, aspirations, and appearances, allowing for endless customization. The game offers a plethora of activities for Sims to engage in, from pursuing careers and hobbies to forming relationships and starting families. With the addition of expansion packs, players can further enrich their gameplay experience with new content such as pets, seasons, and supernatural beings. Immersion and Replayability: One of the standout features of "The Sims 4" is its immersive nature. Players can become deeply invested in the lives of their Sims, forming emotional connections as they guide them through various milestones and challenges. The game's replayability is virtually limitless, thanks to its open-ended nature and the constant stream of updates and expansion packs that introduce fresh content and gameplay mechanics. Community and Mods: "The Sims 4" boasts a vibrant and passionate community of players who share creations, stories, and mods. The availability of user-generated content adds another layer of depth to the game, allowing players to further personalize their experience and explore new possibilities. Conclusion: In conclusion, "The Sims 4" is a captivating and immersive simulation game that offers endless opportunities for creativity and storytelling. With its stunning graphics, rich gameplay features, and thriving community, it continues to delight players of all ages. Whether you're a seasoned Sims veteran or new to the series, "The Sims 4" is sure to provide hours of entertainment and inspiration. Classic EA - you can't get 10 minutes into this game without finding several major problems even indie games manage to avoid with ease. First, you have to install Origin to play the game you just spent 10 hours downloading. After which, if you're as unlucky as me, you find a non-deletable, non-movable shortcut now permanently plastered on your computer's main screen. Terrific. After the hours of installation and subsequent tedious installation of all the other mandatory data-collecting garbage they don't tell you about in the ads, the game itself is a step down from previous installments. It feels a lot like 2 except wonkier to move around. Your characters feel less in your control and more like you're just there to make vague, occasional suggestions. The actual characters look a lot better visually, although it's janky trying to edit their appearance with a mouse and keyboard, and their aspirations feel a lot more limited than the in 3. And you know it wouldn't be a sims game if they didn't deconstruct it down to sell you the "vanilla" game and package the other 95% of the game as dlcs. To read the rest of this review, you must pay a $10 microtransaction.

I'm changing my review for a few reasons. 1. You don't have to use Origin spyware anymore.  They have a new local launcher. 2. The base game is free to play, which invalidates my previous complaint that what amounts to the only virtual dollhouse that exists shouldn't be so heavily gated. 3. It won't be the only virtual dollhouse for long, but it will always be the first.  There will come a time when we point back at the classics. 4. They are participating in Steam sales now. 5. EA has now seen their most wholesome market -- kids who want to play with a dollhouse.  Family-based content has increased and it's beautiful. Remaining Criticisms: 1. The sale prices for the 2023 Spring Sale are fair.  The full prices are ridiculous in a bad way.  Older content should be permanently marked down, and the newest content can be a status symbol by keeping the usual price. Suggestions: 1. Multiplayer features are long overdue for this game.  Being able to visit your friends' worlds would add THE dimension that's missing. 2. While making full-blown modding easier clashes with this game's monetization model, allowing floorplans, worlds, and reskins to be shared via the Workshop (or an EA-centric, proprietary tool even) would be a significant improvement.  Community made past Sims games great, and community can do that again for a broader audience. Overall, not too terrible work recently, EA.  You're not *quite* there yet, but you're close enough to recommend.

The Sims 4 arrived with much fanfare in 2014, promising a new era for Sims fans, but over the years, it has proven to be both a gift and a frustration for players. On the one hand, its improved graphics, sleek Create A Sim (CAS) interface, and unparalleled building tools offered a polished experience. You can fine-tune every detail of a Sim‚Äôs appearance by simply pulling and dragging, something unheard of in earlier versions. The building mode is perhaps the game's greatest triumph, allowing even novice players to create dream homes with ease and precision. However, despite these advancements, The Sims 4 lacks the depth that previous games, like The Sims 2 and The Sims 3, brought to the table. Where The Sims 3 introduced the groundbreaking open world and immense customization options, The Sims 4 feels restrictive. The open world was removed, and much of the rich storytelling and autonomy that made The Sims 2 legendary seem to have been traded for a sleeker visual style. While the base game does a decent job of simulating everyday life, EA‚Äôs reliance on numerous expansion packs, game packs, and stuff packs to complete the experience has frustrated many fans. There are lots of expansion packs and +20 kits, many of which feel overpriced and lack substantial content. Features that were once included in base games, such as toddlers and pools, were only introduced later via patches, raising questions about the game's initial completeness. In the end, The Sims 4 excels in its presentation and ease of use, but it struggles to match the depth and innovation of its predecessors. While it‚Äôs still a fun game, especially with the aid of custom content and mods, long-time Sims fans may feel like it‚Äôs more of a step sideways than a leap forward.

If you consider getting this game but never played sims 3: Get sims 3 instead. Seriously. Technically Sims 3 has one downside. If you play for hours on end you'll need to move your family to a different neighbourhood or your savegame gets corrupted and your game will crash continously untill you export your family and import it in a different savegame. Sims 4 is more buggy, has more pathing issues, has  way, waaaaaaaaay less options both in design as well as gameplay. Sims 4 is inferior to sims 3 in almost every way. Even though I highly recommend Sims 3 above Sims 4, these would be the reasons to get the sims 4 instead of the sims 3: * You can choose your characters walk animation * The tropical island expansion is playable * Cats and dogs in the pets expansion demand less attention and are thus less annoying * Transgender sims * Children are less of a bore * Vampires actually have interesting gameplay (though unlike in the sims 3, in the sims 4 vampires require a completely seperate expansion pack) * Plots have traits, you'll need to eco expansion pack but there are actual mechanics to make eco friendly living an interesting part of the gameplay, sims 3 has a very minor implementation of this (clothing lines instead of dryers), sims 4 has a somewhat better (though  not impressive) implementation * Slightly lighter / more colorful color template. Though sims 4 completely scrapped sims 3's ability to make a personal home decor style, so it barely matters * (considering you have the correct expanion packs) being able to go on holiday to the jungle (though in sims 3 you can go to france, egypt or china...... so that's 1 destinatrion versus  3......

As someone who absolutely adored the Sims when I was younger, I genuinely thought I'd pick up the Sims and dive back into the world after years of going without. Boy was I wrong, and of course as usual; EA comes in to spoil the fun. Can you imagine turning something genuinely beloved into such a hardcore cash grab? I'm use to EA being greedy, however this really broke my heart to see. Why are all the DLC so expensive? Why is the base game pretty much nothing? I remember when the Sims legit came with something, now it feels like there's nothing to do and all the fun is behind a paywall I'll NEVER climb. Seriously, this game is old; I still remember the announcement for it's release. Like the fact that people have to sell an organ(s) just to experience the nostalgic feeling of playing God is wild. Honestly, I'd say pick it up on discount, but jokes on you; there will never be one if you're looking to pick up ALL THE DLC FOR THE GRAND TOTAL OF, yep you guessed it! $939 USD! That's pretty much the cost of lets see, new console, computer (on a budget) down payment on something; take your pick really. Not to mention you're forced to use Origin, and if you don't have it, guess what you're gonna get it anyway! I don't know why this is a thing either, like anything that's attached to Origin forces you to use something despite using Steam, what is the point of buying it on here then? TL;DR: Don't buy this if you actually want to have fun with a game and it's oodles of content. Forced use of another launcher while using steam and all DLC are overpriced for no reason. The base game doesn't have anything to offer without DLC content which is just as expensive. Don't even bother with sales as nothing is ever discounted enough to purchase it all in one go. Do better EA, we know you won't but try.

The Sims 4 2020 review Having now been around now for almost 6 years and still being supported with new expansions, The Sims 4 is showing no signs of going away and honestly, I‚Äôm here for it. It has the same problems, still, as The Sims has always had with AI and pathfinding, and now and then a Sim will steadfastly refuse to follow any kind of instruction or will stubbornly defy you in ways that make you believe in the possibility of computer sentience, but there‚Äôs so much content now that even if you only stretch to a pack or two here and there, there‚Äôs a ton of stuff to do. You can have kids and outfit their rooms; you can buy romantic props for the garden, build greenhouses, have pets and fall in love while walking them in the dog park. There are restaurants and ice cream parlours and a school of magic, if you‚Äôre that way inclined.

Product received for free Originally a $39.99 game that went Free-to-Play. Saw a life flash before my eyes. Overall it was a nice experience playing a franchise I've heard and seen so much about. The music was a surprising highlight. Though the game does start to get tedious repeating the same prompts over and over after a while. Does suffer from quite a few bugs with object placement, stuck sims due to glitchy action, and a queue filled with already accomplished tasks. This is all pretty annoying on top of the sometimes very unresponsive sims that you have to set the same action 3-4 times before it actually gets done. Also at the end of my playthrough I hit a never-ending loading screen (which lasted 30 min before I quit) that made me lose some important progress. These quality of life issues are surprising considering that they are coming from a close to $1,000 dollar game. Just saying I'm not buying DLC if the base game has so many issues with its base functions.

Product received for free Out of stubbornness that The Sims 4 had stripped a load of features from The Sims 3, I had determined never to buy this game, but when it came up as free weekend, I thought I'd give it a chance, since it didn't require me to give EA any money for retrograde games. I've given it a chance, but its character creation controls are so counter-intuitive (the drag on particular parts of the body instead of sliders, the fact that if you have a character with glasses you have to remove the glasses to edit the eyes, not to mention the problems with personality), and its camera controls are dire and a huge step backward that I have given up after 2 hours and will uninstall after posting this review, around 24 hours before the free play ends. For context, this has only happened to me with free weekends once before: with Imperator Rome. Even if I choose not to purchase a game in the long run, I usually enjoy it enough to continue for the entire run of free play time. That is not to say that this game doesn't have good features: the fact that you can now make your sims transgender, transvestite or infertile is a nice addition (I am infertile myself, and it's nice to have some normal representation that doesn't seem to suggest that you are less of a woman if you can't pop out sprogs, or that you are a demented baby-crazy baby snatcher). The walk customisation does add a nice layer of creativity, as do the increased range of voice controls, and the range of looks options (hairstyles, clothes, etc.) is certainly increased. If you can't be bothered to build your own house the hard way, there are some default rooms for you to choose from, but, personally house building the old way was one of the things I loved in earlier games. There are a nice range of options and controls for that aspect of building too. However, for my part, I am utterly unable to work with such terrible camera controls, and the fact that you now have no control over your sim's personality save a bizarre questionnaire at the beginning of character creation is terrible. In The Sims 3, you chose personality traits first, then select from a set of suggested ambitions, or override the system entirely to determine this yourself as the player, now in The Sims 4 you have that choice taken away from you and your favourite author sim from 3 that you recreated wants to be an artist and craves other sim attention, when she used to be shy. I went back and tried another character, same problem, I don't seem to have missed a control somewhere. I even tried the tutorial, same problem. For a player like me, who likes to create lots of different sims to try different goals, ambitions and personalities, this makes the game utterly unplayable, and the controls cement this. In fact, I'm not sure which is the bigger turn off. All that said, I am a 31-year-old gamer playing with a gaming computer and a mouse and keyboard. If you are a 19-year-old playing with a touch screen and no memory of how good previous sims games were, I can see how this game might be fine for you, as for me, I cannot recommend this at all. So much so that this is the first review I have ever posted on any game, and I have thousands and thousands of hours on steam games.

Gameplay experience The controls are very easy to use, with decent hotkeys and navigation. The game isn‚Äôt difficult at all, so I would say it‚Äôs very well balanced. Sims 4 does keep me moderately interested in the game and isn‚Äôt very excited when you play for the long run. In-game choices does not feel that meaningful, where I feel whatever decision you do, basically doesn‚Äôt have consequences or either good or bad rewards. However you play, you still could acquire the same skills, or even apply for the same job regardless of what you do. I can‚Äôt say that doing progress or milestones in the game gives players any rewards. So, I feel unsatisfied regarding this. I.e., making your way through life in the game doesn‚Äôt bring that much joy. I don‚Äôt feel like aging up in-game gives me satisfaction. Presentation & Immersion The game itself doesn‚Äôt quite have a story, so you basically have to create one of your own. Even by doing so, it doesn‚Äôt feel that much interesting because it doesn‚Äôt really matter. For time to time, you often feel very immersive into the game. If you follow and play with a few sims at a time, you feel immersed into their life and actions. Sims 4 is design very well. The visual art and style of the game is very appealing, but not much have changed since the previous game Sims 3. The same goes for the sound and music, this is also very engaging, but still a lot like its previous title. The HUD is very user-friendly and easy to use. Design & Technical Aspects I wouldn‚Äôt say that the game is design more than average mechanical wise. Because sometimes the game feels just more less natural and unrealistic. Sims 4 does have a lot of content, but many of these looks weird in my opinion, and there is lack of content in different areas in the game. I.e., the curtains just to mention. There are even lots of different DLC‚Äôs with even more content, which is also very expensive. The AI in this game is poor in my opinion. You cannot rely on the ‚Äúautonomy‚Äù function in the game settings. Sometimes a lot of actions just feel unnatural and sometimes I just feel the AI‚Äôs just do whatever stupid things they want to do without the influence of household members. ‚ÄúWhy would the mother read a book and turn on the music while the baby is asleep?‚Äù These kinds of stuff happen all the time and is very annoying. Game settings does give certain ways of adjusting the game and graphics. Still, I feel there are some settings missing from the previous titles. I.e., the level of autonomy. Here you could choose between ‚Äúoff‚Äù or ‚Äúfull‚Äù. And I do remember there were different options in Sims 3. Since release I‚Äôve been experiencing technical issues and glitches. I.e., for a year ago, there was an insult bug which made people insult each other all the time. The bug existed for a long time and made interactions with other sims impossible. It obviously made me quit for a certain time. The most recent bugs I‚Äôve encountered is tings like ‚Äúget leftovers‚Äù. Sims gets a new plate out of the fridge again and again without eating them. Causing plates with food being placed around every space of the kitchen etc. If you get a newborn, be prepared to have issues interacting with them. Because I‚Äôve had A LOT. Many tasks in ‚Äúthe queue‚Äù got stuck and couldn‚Äôt be cancelled. Which made me must restart and quit the game several times. While the baby cries og floats in the air just by itself. You can‚Äôt do nothing because it would not make you interact. Every day in a sim‚Äôs world, this happens. You can‚Äôt go one day without experiencing small to moderate bugs. Final Considerations I‚Äôm not satisfied with the game. The bugs, content, and game overall just fell more less real and stiffer than its previous title. You can‚Äôt even own a car, you can‚Äôt even see the town you live in properly, career options are more less available than ever. The experience feels more limited than it should be. A game like this could bring out so much more. And for a game to be 7 years old, I find it hard to be that many bugs and issues which seems too basic to even exist. The replay value is low, because if feels very monotonous and repetitive with every household you play. It‚Äôs kind of straightforward going from A to B. Even though it issues, I still feel the game gives a good value for its price because of it being free to play. If you‚Äôre looking for a game to play by growing a household with an expecation to play in the long run, I would recommend you not play this game. Summary Gameplay Experience: 17 / 25 Presentation & Immersion: 20 / 25 Design & Technical Aspects: 15 / 25 Final Considerations: 12 / 25 Poor: 64 / 100 Performance or gameplay falls significantly below the passing mark. Requires substantial improvements and may have critical flaws or issues, Not Recommended.

The Sims 4 is that game your angry older sister played growing up. Set in the fictional country of SimNation, and no I didn't make that up, you play as a sort of god-like figure that creates humanoids known as Sims and lets them loose to pursue their dreams, ambitions, and make a name for themselves in a world that is hilariously easy to accomplish your goals in. Property is also insultingly affordable. There's apparently some sort of lore for the Sims universe, but I don't know it and it doesn't really come up outside of some flavor text every now and then so instead I'm just going to make one up. Set a thousand years after a great war between the Sims and the Villagers from the great Animal Crossing Empire, the Sims of SimNation live in terror of the great mustache man in the sky (me) who makes them do weird things on command and also maybe teaches them how to use firearms to KILL. You know how the Sims works, but lets pretend that you don't or I hit you with a brick hard enough so you don't remember. You start by either taking control of a Sim, or a family of Sims, or lets be more honest as to what you're going to do, make a new Sim from scratch that is either some kind of OC or just fantasized versions of you and your friends. Don't feel ashamed, we've all done it. From here you move your Sim or Sims to a house or plot of land that is offensively cheap, and then either get them settled in or build them an abode to dwell in like some sort of digital goblin. From here you can either set them loose and let them do what they want, or control them and decide their fate. There really isn't a wrong way to play the Sims, unless you're one of those Whickedwhims guys. Then there is a wrong way to play the Sims. Even now, the evil seed of what you've done germinates within you. Don't be fooled by my Steam time, I have hours in this game going into the triple digits over the years. Am I an expert on the Sims? No. Do I need to be? No. For me, the Sims isn't really a game you super get into, but instead just something you putz around on every now and then just to see what happens, or just something to stream to your friends on a really slow Saturday.  But keep in mind, I am not the target audience for this game.  My version of the Sims has xenocide and death tolls reaching levels formally known as ‚ÄúUntold‚Äù A billion lives were not enough for Dirk. The Sims is a dollhouse simulator, you're there to either experiment, just have fun, or live out a fantasy. Sims 4 helps with this by adding milestones and achievements for your Sims, the more you focus on your Sims goals, the more points you get to spend on neat little buffs and doodads. Anything from becoming a great artist, to advancing your career, to kissing a girl (this one is hard), to stealing anything that isn't nailed down to the ground. Its neat to see Sims actually have a form of quests now. Unless they appeared in previous games and I just don't remember, like I said, literally years. The Sims 4 however has a rather neat mood system where you can tell exactly how your Sim is feeling at a glance, stuff like Happy, sad, flirty, hungry, angry, or just chilling, you are also presented with reasons as to WHY your Sims are either in a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• or good mood. I've seen complaints about it from other people, but I like it, it gives context to your Sims when you're playing it as just a game and not a sex dungeon simulator. Sims 4 also moves away from the open world that was featured in Sims 3, and instead goes back to the instanced zones like Sims 1 and 2. Its a step back, sure, but at the same time it means my computer doesn't light up faster than a Vietnamese jungle in 1968, so I'm all for it. I played them beside one another once and yeah,  Sims 4 actually does run a lot better on my PC, so it might have been the right decision, even if it does make the world feel smaller. Just playing the free to play version, you have a few things to do. You can take your sim(s) to a bar, go clubbing, get jacked at the gym, enjoy a park, see an art museum, or just kind of hang out in public areas. Between the two towns and the free-to-build town, you can actually stay busy for a bit without spending money. As a base game, the Sims 4 is just ‚ÄúThe Sims‚Äù You are simming, you don't get any of the crazy stuff like story packs or whatever that Star Wars DLC is about. Star Wars, probably. So, you like the Sims? Are a huge Sims fan now, want to maybe get a bit deeper into the series? Well, then you can look forward to purchasing the content packs for the Sims at a cheap price! Ha Hahahha Ha ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. At full price, without discount, the Sims 4 will cost you about $1,500 Canadian dollars. That's about $1120 American Freedom Dollars. That's not just steep, that's ridiculous. To put in into perspective, Sims 3 was already pushing it at $500. So what's the strategy here? Well, you wait for sales, and unless you really want to, you don't buy everything. What you want to do is go through the DLC and pick out what you really want. Want Vacations? Get the Vacation expansion, want to experience University with your Sims? There's an expansion for that. Etc. From what I can tell you can mostly ignore the ‚ÄúStuff‚Äù packs. I guess they add some neat stuff for your Sims to play around with, but in the long run I doubt they're all that worth it. What else can you do if you want the Sims flavors but don't want to pay that price? Well, the Sims and Sims 2 are basically still around, you can't buy them from the EA store, but you can still find them if you look hard enough. Do you know how many boxed copies of The Sims 2 they made? Do you know how many are still sealed? I have three of them. But, there are those people that live and breath the Sims, and buy literally every expansion and every stuff pack AS they were released. It doesn't hit those people as hard as it would someone just getting into the games, because for them its like 10 to 50 dollars every few months. An MMO sub costs more than that in the long run. But yeah, at the current state of things, getting into the Sims 4 is a tall order. They're also very peculiar people. Go into the gallery and just look at some of the more popular Sims that get uploaded to the EA servers. You'll start to see a pattern of the very specific kind of men and women these people are into. Very chiseled, they're very metropolitan looking Sims that actually remind me of those urbansexual characters you see in Second Life videos on Youtube. What else should I cover? Oh yeah. At this point, The Sims basically covers everyone. Everything from sexualities, ethnicities, one (1) religion, and even pronouns, something I personally don't get, but hey man, you do you. You can make the Sims as progressive, traditional, or just as neutral as you want, you just need to be a bit creative. Do I recommend The Sims 4? As a game, yeah. As a product? No. If you're looking for just ‚ÄúThe Sims‚Äù then the free to play version should be perfect for you. But if you want the full Sims experience? Then you'll have to pony up a bit. The Sims 4: Free to play gets 6 made up Sim language out of 10. The Sims' original concept was for a house building game. I tried to find a translator to say ‚ÄúJoin the curator‚Äù in Simlish but I couldn't find a good one.

Recommended now that the base game includes toddlers, and obviously much better if you have the expansions packs too. What Sims 4 lacks in personality (which Sims 2 definitely had) and open-world creativity (Sims 3) it makes up for in other ways, especially if gameplay-enhancing mods are added to make it more realistic and the sims a bit more "human". For me though I particularly enjoy the building mechanics. Also I've had no corruption issues that I experienced in my Sims 2 game (broken memories in Sims 2 often caused this). I also like the fact you can share sims and lots with others via the Gallery.  So I guess I'm (just about) in the "fan" camp, although I do find the fact you can't create your own unique World (as you could in Sims 3) pretty restricting.

Although this is the steam version, I have clocked in well over 2,000 hours on the origin version. This game is a load of fun. I will go over the good and the bad parts of this game. Starting with the bad. - Load screens. Loads of them. You can't visit a neighbors house without a load screen popping up. - The visuals on this game may not be to everyones taste, as this game took a more "cartoony" approach compared to the others being a bit more "realistic" looking. As for the good. - The ability to play more than one household on the same save file. This is something the other Sims games did not do. You were stuck with the household you chose first and couldn't play any other created family. As a person who indulges in stories, this decision was an absolute must. The fact I could play as one family and progress on them to a certain point, then play as a different family and visit the first to admire my previous work is a real feel-good feeling to me. - The fact that you can visit any purchased DLC world without needing to create a separate save file. You can actually visit any world you want with whatever Sim you were playing as without any problem. - The CAS (create-a-sim) is easily the best in the franchise. You can mold and shape your sims effortlessly in this game by simply grabbing nearly any face part (eyes, nose, jaw, chin, ears, etc) and any body part (aside from hands) and mold them in any way you want. The only thing lacking is create-a-pattern, but that isn't a big deal in my opinion. - The graphics in this game are best in the series. Although this is my opinion, I hated the "realistic" approach in the previous Sims, where Sims 2 felt dead and empty aesthetic-wise. This game feels like it has more life and color compared to the previous games. The sims themselves look great as well. The ones in Sims 3 looked too similar (and a bit creepy), whereas they look colorful and far more appealing here. - There's never a shortage on things to do. Sims 4 had a rough start, but has come a long way since its initial release in 2016. Even the base game offers a fairly good experience, but with some of the DLC (my recommended would be Vampires and Island Living), there's always ways to enjoy the game. - This game is a lot easier on computers. There's always someone complaining about the lack of an open world, but Sims 3 is an example of they we don't have an open world. The game was horrible taxing and had bad performance issues (unless you used certain mods) to run everything that was going on in the game. Sims 4 fixed that by separating the worlds and allowing the player to access any place at any time. This decision has resulted in the Sims 4 being easier on computers than the previous installments. Although I agree that it's pointless to visit a neighbors house you have to go through a load screen, but with since we can visit any lot, any world, at any time, with very little cost to your computers performance, I'll take the sacrifice. In general, I find this game to be fantastic in many different ways and to be the best in the franchise.

It is something wrong when you play a game and constantly think one thing: I am missing a lot of game content, because 700$. Jesus, EA got really greedy because of it own fan base.

I purchased this game at full price, $30 or so on steam. No money back or a nifty DLC that can replace the money lost. OH BUT YOU GET A $5 content pack with less content that what a modder can do in their spare time. You get a 6th of you paid for in return, none of the DLCs that have equal value to their full game(at the time) which by the way there is no reason to price a DLC at the same value as the game itself if it doesn't include the same amount of content as the base game. Imagine buying a full priced game, and then there is a DLC with a tenth of the amount of content with the same price tag that was included by default in previous titles. EA has went from a company I loved and held dear as a teen back in Sims 1 and 2 to now being an absolute garbage fire of a greedy company. obviously there would be more negative reviews but i'm sure those who bought the game very much gave up on it and left it to collect dust in their library. I would refund this if I could but obviously I can't,,, Smart play EA, but like the age old saying; "Fool me once" Next time EA throws out another sims or game with even worse quality of content and more heftier prices for what should have been base game to begin with; Watch to sales plummet. Nobody wins when you get too greedy.

Over 1100 hours and counting. Bought all Expansions, Packs, and Kits. The reason why I keep playing this game is the community that supports this game. The endless possibilities. And if you bought all the Expansion Pack (Cottage Living being my latest), there's no limit of sims that can live in your world. I have about 700 playable sims and counting. I have about 1400 sims total in my world. They way all your sims, even from different worlds interact with each other, is very good. One of the best NPC interactions of any game for your non played sims with your playable sims. Hence, that's what this game is all about. If Sims 5 comes out, it's hard to top this platform.

I (try to) play The Sims purely for nostalgia reasons, but wouldn't recommend the game to new players. Electronic Arts (EA) is not dedicated to improving their products; instead releasing new content that hasn't been properly vetted for bugs. The Sims 4 has been receiving this kind of broken content for years - the result is a game that has immersion and mechanic-disrupting problems piled on top of even more of the same; these bugs simply are never addressed by the developers. In many cases these expansions have led to the corruption of save files that have years of game-play, making them unrecoverable. The modding community picks up the slack on EA's own lack of initiative to make the product function well (often for free). It's a pretty dismal arrangement that speaks volumes to EA's priorities: if you need a hint, it isn't the consumer's experience with the product. There's definitely room for competition in the life-sim genre of video games.

I do love this game deep down but like, god. All packs add up to like 1200$ and half of em are useless or broken. You have to have custom content to make the game playable but you have to update it like every month/update or your interface ends up screwed or your game is unplayable. its fun if you have money to blow and a crazy amount of time to spend making a full family and all of their outfit, then designing their whole house just for like a very boring long term game. Not much to do other than grind skill and get a partner for your sim (if you didn't just make one cause all base sims are ugly) and raise kids and have them ALL end up with the agressive trait for some reason (4/5 of all toddlers i've had in games end up with it and you can't get rid of it) and then you have to regrind those same skills on a different sim. Just very repeated, very time consuming, and very expensive game.

I LOVE the Sims. I just want to put that out there.. Before anyone calls me a hater. I have saves on ALL the Sims. Including 4 In the past it's been blocky and clunky. Won't recommend at this time. I've been playing the sims for years, and with every release I've been more and more disappointed in EA. I was super, super excited for the horse pack. I loved horses on the sims 3, and I love playing my sims in a ranch/cottage setting. However, the horse pack release was super disappointing. I spent $40 for a game that I couldn't even play initially, as the pack had been riddled with bugs. But, EA developers were quick to fix said bugs, so I put up with it. Now though, I can't play the sims 4 as it won't launch on my laptop. I've tried everything, but the EA app just won't work. Whenever I try to launch the game itself, it redirects me to the EA home screen but then it disappears literally a second later. There are just too many bugs and glitches for this game to cost so much money. Plus, the horses like so cartoony. The sims 3 horses looked so much better and more realistic imo But, I guess that doesn't matter when I can't even launch the game now. If EA would fix all of these issues, I would recommend this game in a heartbeat. But, as of right now, there are just too many issues.

Bought this on the sale a couple of weeks back. I have played a few sessions and I ragequit the game every time because there was constantly bugs with the activity queue where one would get stuck and my characters could never go to bed or use the restroom and would pass out instead of taking care of their needs, requiring me to exit to the main menu and load back in to fix it every time. This gets especially annoying if you have a kid and the parents get stuck in a loop and won't feed the child until someone comes and takes the kid away. The game is constantly updated with new DLC but they never actually update the game itself or do bugfixes. The game still does not recognize my GTX 1660 because it's "too new" and now the game won't even start because I moved it to a new hard-drive and I've uninstalled it and re-installed it completely several times, including installing it on the same old hard-drive again. I'll take it as a sign to uninstall this game and never buy anything from EA ever again. Good riddance. The game has been out for several years and it's still super buggy. It's clear that EA is just focusing entirely on selling more DLC instead of fixing the game. EDIT: I have since played the game some more (for some reason) since my initial review. The game has been updated a few times with some (supposed) bug fixes. Unfortunately it seems like most of my issues are still not fixed. I had to remove the game completely and reinstall it to get it to work again. It does recognize my graphics card now however. The issues with the activities are still there so I still have to re-log quite often which is super-annoying. I seem to be able to place beds next to walls now though, my sims don't warp through walls after sleeping any more so I guess that's an improvement. Still can't really recommend the game in it's current state but at least some of the bugs have been fixed. Is it an indication that they are working on fixing the base game instead of making more DLC? Probably not. I guess we'll have to wait and see.

The current state of this game is genuinely and absolutely pathetic. Fans of this game series have complained about consistent bugs, presumably since the game's release, but until the most recent update which made the game free, I luckily found myself spared from most of these despite playing for years. However, after the latest update, the game has become literally unplayable without cheats or constant saving so that a player can reset if a sim randomly dies. I have rarely faced any issues before recently, but now I consistently experience sims dying in 24 hours (a rather common bug, apparently...) Additionally, I have been playing a sim with a passion for gardening, and have come to see many, many bugs within the gardening systems. Not only have I had plants and crops revert back to seedlings seemingly randomly (I can only presume this is a bug and not a feature), grow when they are out of season (or vice versa; becoming dormant when they are in season), as well as the cowplant interaction to eat cake not appearing when it should (when the cake-shaped tongue is out) until I debugged the object. I can only assume that other aspects of the game have begun to malfunction similarly. And while this can't necessarily be considered a bug, sims develop fears in a very poorly designed way- my main sim, who lives with and is dating a ghost, as well as having the occult trait and ghosts in their likes, developed a fear of ghosts from seeing their girlfriend possess something (a very, very common occurrence in the household), as well as gaining a fear of cowplants despite petting, feeding and playing with their cowplant every 12 hours for several in-game seasons. And while I have experienced these issues in particular, others I know have not, and have experienced completely different bugs and glitches that I haven't, making it even more difficult to prepare for what issues may come my way. The issues others have faced are more related to relationships, as the most recent update has made them completely unmanageable for some players. As a game which has been extremely popular and adored for years, which previously had quite the sizeable cost, it is genuinely shocking and baffling to see the amount of issues with even the most basic aspects of the gameplay.

I want to like this game but the base game seems very limited. It exists pretty much solely to get you to download the dlc. It doesn't feel like a full game. I saw the bit about it scanning your computer as a requirement for play, and I really can't think of any benign reason for that? If you are playing competitively, it makes sense that they would monitor for cheating, but someone playing solo - well, what they do is their business. And as soon as you accept legally that they can monitor you, what's to stop them accessing your microphone or camera, or just selling off whatever naughty pics you took of yourself, as happened to the celebs in the iphone scandal a few years ago? I do like the free mods, but again they actually seem more limited than earler versions. I noticed a lot of modders are now selling mods for this game. It is not a good sign that people are willing to pay for content, as that means the owner of the IP is not meeting the demand of the marketplace with the game. Looking as sims 4, it doesn't seem to be as successful as sims 3 - and sims 2 had a big cultural impact. Maybe it is just too dated a concept now? I feel meh to be honest. The DLC is on sale, but nothing of it really excites me, and the weird way EA says they can block you from playing your own game after you paid them for it makes me ponder the wisdom of purchases. What if they decide to block everyone without the correct gender pronouns? Or anyone under six foot? I mean, they can, that's the point, it's crazy, but that is legally what they can do, and they don't seem to be required to give you a refund. So do you actually buy the game or are you just "leasing an experience", as they say? Because I'd have to say it reminds me a heck of a lot of the John Deere Tractors fiasco.

I've been playing Sims since 2001 and unfortunately I can't recommend Sims 4 for MANY reasons. 1. Greedy practices EA do what EA does. There is currently $765 worth of DLC... $765. Most of the stuff in those packs is stuff that would have been included in full packs in the past. Vampires are a $20 pack... $20 for a life-state and a small neighborhood. Supernatural in Sims 3 was $40 with so much more on offer. Sure, it didn't have the skills of Vampires but those skills were kinda one dimensional. $20 for camping? $20 for a jungle adventure? Seriously? Stuff packs maximum are worth $5. No more. At launch, there was HUGE (deserved) backlash for so many missing basic features. Like pools, hot tubs, terrain tool, and more. Some of this stuff was sold back to you as DLC. Also: My First Pet Stuff. That pack is the EPITOME of EA's greed. 2. Lack of any depth and meaningful gameplay Sims 4 just feels so hollow. It doesn't feel like a Sims game. It feels like my choices and my Sims' stories simply don't matter or make a difference. When I take my Sims places, I just have to complete a small checklist and boom: all done! No real weight or impact is made. In other games, my choices made an impact (moreso in 3 and 2 than in 1 but still) such as divorcing your spouse and getting arrested (in 3). Choices carried weight and Sims 4 doesn't have that weighted choice. It feels like you do a thing... and that's it. No impact or consequences. You just go on as if it didn't happen. Due to the emptiness of the game, it gets incredibly boring incredibly quickly and I can't play for more than an hour at a time. Complexity does not equal depth and meaningful gameplay. Blizzard Entertainment still hasn't learned that yet either. You can easily complete a pack's content within a few hours if you work at it hard enough. 3. Retraction of Features Sims 4 removed one of the best things the series introduced: open world. I know some people had issues with Sims 3 myself included but the open world is seriously awesome. Despite how bad the story progression (this can be turned off in 3) could get, your choices had impact due to how others around you would react. Sims 4? No open world. No progression. Nothing. It doesn't exist. What about Create-A-Style? NOPE! What you see is what you get. When the game launched, it had 88 missing features... EIGHTY EIGHT! Included in previous base games. EA/Maxis' reason for the removal of CAS and OW was due to engine limitations... total ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. One mod with open-world Sims 4 maps has just been released and another is on its way. You can't pull that crap when fans can surpass those "limits" effortlessly. Sims 4 prioritized artstyle and system specs over actual gameplay. After six years (seven in 2021), EA/Maxis still haven't made the Sims 4 any more compelling or fun to play. 4. The big one: the Sims themselves are boring and infuriating The Sims in the Sims 4 have the exact same personality as the other. I know, I know; they have the emotion system and traits. That's just it; that's all they have! The emotion system, while cool in theory, is so easily manipulated and every sim is affected the same way so everyone is essentially the same person. Also the emotions mean... nothing. Working out with one emotion versus another does jack for gameplay purposes. Sims 2, 3, and 4 both have an issue of nearly identical actions, but in 2 and 3 at least some of those actions changed things up. Sims 4's actions all blend together. Nearly every computer action in Sims 4 (as an example) is the same: hacking money, playing games, chatting with friends all seem exactly the same. There's no variety. Sims in 1, 2, and 3 also did what you told them to do and did things on their own if they felt they needed to (such as pee if they needed to do so and were uncommanded). Sims in 4 will fight you. They seem to want to do their own thing apart from what you want. Want your Sim to get food? Nope! He's painting a cheeseburger. Want your Sim to shower? Nope. Traits themselves are hollow. Adults get three. THREE! Sims 3 Adults got five. These traits are just very minor changes to the Sims as well. In Sims 3, these traits would affect a great variety of things such as skill speed, your progression, and overall experience your Sims would have. In Sims 4, the traits you pick seem to have very little effect on anything you do. Maybe a minor change here and there but otherwise it's not noticeable at all. Overall, the Sims 4 lacks depth and basic features while still being milked to death by EA. If you absolutely MUST have this game, get it on a huge discount (and don't buy My First Pet Stuff if you value your wallet and your pride). I remember being intrigued about Sims 4 when it was coming out and how disappointed I was in it. In 2020, I still feel disappointed. I couldn't recommend it in 2014 and I still can't recommend it now. I know some Sims 4 fans will probably be ready to jump down my throat at this review because they adore it. You can enjoy Sims 4! I never said you couldn't! I just don't think Sims 4 lives up to the expectations this series has made for itself over the years. At first I thought I had outgrown the Sims with Sims 4, but I literally sat down for hours on end in Sims 3 just recently for a week! It's not the fans who grew up, it's the series that abandoned itself. I have more playtime on my Origin by the way.

It's the Sims. I don't think I need to explain the game to anyone. So instead I'll explain some things for those that may have not "bought in" yet. The game has gone free to play. But don't let that fool you. This is a game by EA. The base game is a hollow shell and you will get bored very quickly. There's only really any content or things to do if you buy the DLCs. How much for all the DLCs? As of this review: just under 1,000$! Cheap I know, a real STEAL some would say. But all jokes aside if you're interested in playing you will want to pick up some DLCs but NEVER EVER buy any unless they are -50% to -75% off or more. The DLCs are egregiously overpriced for the content they add.

If you're still on the fence about diving into The Sims 4 and its seemingly endless DLC packs, let me just tell you‚Äîthere's a lot to love. The base game going free-to-play was a smart move by EA, opening up the world of Sims to tons of new players, but let's be real‚Äîthe real fun lies in those expansions. Now, you could easily sink a small fortune into the DLCs, but here's a little life hack: if you figure out how to acquire these packs by, let‚Äôs say, more creative means, you might just see your social life improve. I‚Äôm talking about a 5x increase in your chances of snagging a girlfriend. I mean, who wouldn‚Äôt be impressed by your meticulously designed Sim world where every season changes, your Sims have pets, and they can go to college, all thanks to the Seasons, Cats & Dogs, and Discover University packs? And let‚Äôs be honest‚Äîwe all know Sims is a game played exclusively by hot women.

XD From DLC i bought only 2 bigger packs: Get to Work and Get Together, from small packs: Vampires and Jungle Adventure. Be careful if you have The Sims 4 on Origin already then DON'T install the Steam version!!!! Thats why: i wanted to try the Steam version and i installed it here too ( i have Origin version already installed), now the Steam version ask me to login again to an Origin account, after i tried the Steam version i went back to my Origin savegame. What kills me is that they have also made this free to play screwing over anyone who actually paid for the base game initially (And offered nothing for compensation). The Sims is my favourite game ever. I have over 3000 hours played in Origin. DO NOT BUY THIS GAME. It is broken. EA keeps releasing broken DLC because they know people will buy their crap anyway. If you love the Sims, stop buying DLC until the game is fixed. The game is utterly unplayable without mods and there are so many constant updates with new crap that it's just an utter pain to constantly have to update your mods, only for a new thing to break when the EA team adds an item that breaks the whole game. Honestly, Sims 3 had so much more content that made it immersive. Instead of only being able to walk around the block a bit, sims 3 let you explore the entire area and even had Easter Eggs, such as finding the unicorn- to which I wont spoil how. Anyways, the graphics are sub-par at best without custom content which takes ages to do and a lot of them glitch or dont work properly. Sims is getting greedier and greedier with all these expensive DLC that honestly should be part of the base game. I mean I have to pay 14$ to have laundry accessories? Dont waste your time unless you dont mind spending hours finding custom content that works ( WHICH IS HARD, A LOT OF MESHES ARENT ATTACHED AND SUCH) Overall, If you dont mind a simple family simulator then this is fine, however if you are looking for a sims 3 upgrade this would be considered the opposite in my opinion. Even downgraded the sliders.

Pros: - It is easy to build - There are plenty of options to build - even in several stories, basement included. - The job opportunities seems to be many - Whether it is a plus or a minus, I do not know - but the sim-logic is pretty much the same - it looks pretty - You can pay taxes over the computer - You can to a great extend customize your Sims when you create them Cons: - It will be launched through Origin. So, if you can find it cheaper on Origin, buy it there - there are no achievements, a couple of cards, but that it all you get from buying it on Steam. So, unless you really need it to be in your Steam library, there is little point in buying it for steam if you can find it cheaper for Origin - The house maid seems pretty incompetent - You cannot make either the housemaid or the gardener come several time a week or even decide which day they should come - The game crash ever so often (my system should be well capable of running it, and yet it has it by, among others, crashing every first time I launch it) and it crash randomly when I play - It will be really expensive if you want all of the DLCs - Sims have it by cancelling whatever commands you queued up for no reason at all - The plants do not seem to live that long without constant care - It seems there is no auto-save - which would be greatly appreciated since the game crash so often - If you lock you door, and then go somewhere else, when you come back, all of your "guests" (read hostages) are gone - I guess at some point, it will just be rinse and repeat, but I am not entirely sure on that one yet. Conclusion: It is pretty fun to make your sim(s) go on all sorts of mischief and terrorizing the neighborhood, but that it still crashes ever so often despite its release in 2017 - I wonder why EA has not fixed this issue yet - of if they ever will. With that said, if you can deal with the fact that the game often crashes, sure, it is a great game. Though, I would not buy it other than on sale. Same with the DLCs.

The sims 4 has finally gone free to play and ultimately I must say this game is very very enjoyable. If you want the short answer, definitely give it a try. The base game is decent fun with mods and getting packs can enhance your experience (given you research before you buy them) I am a very big fan of the sims 4, its the first and only sims game i have played up to this point. But after playing all the DLC packs, and playing for over 1,000 hours (Holy ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, also steam time is wrong) I feel I need to give the sims 4 a proper review treatment. I want to preface this by saying I really do love this game but after playing it for so long I have a bit of a mixed love for it. This base game is empty, you need expansions to get the full picture, the whole game revolves around these packs. You will at some point be blocked off from enjoying the whole thing without mods or buying a pack. There is fun to be had but it doesn't get into much depth, you will get bored if you try to make this into a serious life sim without packs/mods. But the problem with the packs has become very pronounced over this past year (2023), having every single expansion is great it gives you so many options, however it makes the game so bloated every pack wants you to experience the whole thing right now (except for Seasons and Growing Together) so each pack is always begging for you to do something with them. Another problem with the packs is how it really starts to show they are reaching the limits of this game's engine. You can update games as much as you want but they have a limit of game changing updates before the cracks start to show, and that is definitely the case here. The game slows down constantly, NPCs are confused, the game will randomly soft-reset all the characters. Its a mess, this game is 10 years old and it shows. But especially now the sims 4 seems to be grasping for any money it can with these packs. The last pack at the time of writing this, For Rent, is extremely empty, I thought it would be fun but there is so little content there and what is there is clearly unfinished and very buggy. However this is sold with a 40$ price tag, same as packs like seasons and high school years, when in comparison this has the content of a 20$ pack, not even. Some of these packs need to be lowered in price, Get To Work for example, is so small in comparison to most packs and a lot of the pack is broken becuase its as old as this game. Still 40$. The Sims 4 itself is not a bad game, its a really decent life sim and I am glad its free now. But the pack system they have built into this game is ultimately going to kill it. I honestly cannot encourage you to invest into all the packs like I tried to I know the sims 5 (Project renee) is coming soon, however they have stated that will be more of a spin-off and that they are just planning to keep making sims 4 content for the foreseeable future. (Also there will be a item shop or battlepass in the Sims 5 which makes me afraid already) There's only so many 40$ packs you can churn out before A. you run out of ideas, B. people stop buying, or C. the game starts breaking under the amount of updates. I suppose this is less of a review and more of a rant on the current state of this game, but I feel its important to point out for this game. Point is thats what I have to say about it, EA please dont run this game into the ground anymore than you have, just let it go
