I love this game and it is really hard to explain why. I think it is a game you are either going to love or hate. To me this is my go-to game just to relax and have some fun. I don't have to move through a quest line or go kill mobs to advance, I just sit, relax and play. There are aspirations you can work on and career goals you can do. However, I totally live vicariously through my Sims. Where else can I be a vampire one moment and a witch the next or maybe even an alien or mermaid. Where else would I be able to change my wardrobe on a whim or constantly upgrade my house to being the biggest and most beautiful in the neighborhood. I do like to play a lot of the challenges that are available from Sim character challenges to building challenges. The create-a-Sim and the building features in this game are easy to use and you have more functionality than you did in previous Sim games. One of the challenges I was involved with was having an alien impregnate 10 sims without them discovering that he was an alien. Another was creating an underground bunker with just the cheapest and lowest end essentials (bed, stove, etc) and one way of making money (easel, guitar, etc) and you put two sims in there to survive. I now have a 3 level bunker, my sims are maxed out on their wealth, they have had 12 generations and none of them have left the bunker. The children kept wanting to leave for school though so that just added another level to the challenge to keep them from leaving as you leveled up their skills before aging them up. My point is, there are a lot of ideas available to make the game fun and challenging if you get bored. I have played all the previous Sims games and I have been playing Sims 4 since its release. I do enjoy playing Sims 4 and I even still play my previous versions of Sims 2 and Sims 3. I did prefer Sims 3 for awhile but as more DLC's came out for Sims 4, I started to enjoy Sims 4 more than Sims 3. I did have to re-purchase the Base game in order for it to appear in Steam, but I did get it on sale and I felt it was worth paying the money to re-purchase the base game. All my DLC's are still there, they just don't appear in Steam as having been purchased. But to me, that is OK. I knew that even launching Sims through Steam, I would still need Origin as it is similar to how some other 3rd party games launch, but it is nice that I can launch from Steam and be part of discussions and chat groups that are available in Steam. I know that having to have an Origin login upsets a lot of people, but having been familiar with this 3rd party game play, I was not surprised or upset by it as I have many games that launch from a 3rd party platform. I know a lot of people are upset about the cost of purchasing all the DLC's and, in hindsight, I guess I did spend a lot over the years in purchasing the DLC's but I do love them all and it would be hard for me to choose my favorite DLC to suggest to purchase. I know in the discussion area, people are always asking which DLC to buy, but it will really depend on what interests you, from having babies/toddlers to pets to being famous to just being a vampire. It will depend on what your interests are. I do have a couple of Mods in my game but they are not really game or design changing Mods. I use one Mod that allows me to have an increased number of members in clubs (as I have a huge community of Sims) and I have another mod that allows my Sims to be members of more clubs. However, the modding community for this game is huge. I have several game friends that have hundreds of mods in their game that changes everything from appearance of their Sims to being able to be a serial killer. I would recommend this game and even though this game has is pros and cons, there is no perfect game.

It is what it is. Mediocre The game itself is pretty good. Don't get me wrong, I bet some people adore this version of The Sims. The problem is, it had so many great features brutally taken away (like the ability to freely change colors of furniture), that it's hard not to dislike it. It really sucks that you gotta buy so many DLCs to get absolutely anything. In a way, I think they overdid it. There are SO. MANY. WORLDS., and the loading screen is the most annoying thing - Sims 3 didn't have that. Sure, certain users faced huge lag with the open world, but it was way better for me to have a tiny lag every few hours, rather than looking at the loading screen for the frustrating 10 to 20 seconds anytime I want to move around. JUST LET ME PLAY MY GAME??? The sims do not listen to what I tell them to do, all of the actions I tell my sims to do get randomly cancelled, random dishes that do not get washed, bad pathfinding??? God. Sims 3 >>> Sims 4. Now I am stuck with a kitchen that has 5 different tones of gray and 3 tones of black.

After logging over 1000 hours on EA, let me tell you‚Ä¶ Are you looking for a distraction that will consume your life? Want to create a floor plan just to see how that one rug from IKEA will look? Curious about what happens when you take the ladder out of the pool? Or maybe you just want to spend more time managing your mods and CC (over 8000 items personally, mind you) than actually playing the game? If your answer is a yes, then I HIGHLY recommend this game! It‚Äôs a delightful time where you can spend 10 hours crafting the perfect family or 80 hours building a dream house, only to lose it all because you forgot to back up your saves. (oops on my part honestly) You‚Äôll find yourself grateful for the ability to control a Sim's life when your own feels a bit too chaotic. Whether you choose to give your Sim the life you never had or embark on a "rags to riches" journey that ends in just getting the kitchen built, or even transform your Sim into an in-game Joe Goldberg(not saying that I did that...)‚Äîit's all in your hands! The only limits to your fun is how much cash you‚Äôre willing to pour into expansion packs and how much patience you have for mods and CC. If you're open to expansion packs or a crazy mod folder, I say check it out if you somehow haven't since its release 10 years ago. However, if you‚Äôre sticking to the base game without any additional content or mods, I‚Äôd recommend steering clear. (Packs owned: Dream Home Decorator, Cottage Living, Paranormal Stuff Pack, Tiny Living, Strangerville, Seasons, Laundry Day Stuff, City Living, Get to Work)

Disgruntled steam deck user review: The game starts once, be it incredibly janky to start with, black screens, DRM EA Play launcher messages etc etc. So once you've logged in, you get to play.. Great 5 hours in you will give it a rest, you've played enough Sims today. You go to boot the game the next day. black screen and crashes. So you think, ah, maybe I'll change the version of proton, well.. That replaces your entire proton area and save file. So now that 5 hours is somewhere in the void, because there's no cloud sync apparently. So.. To EA Take some of your developers off of the DLC cash cow team, and place them on the core game team. Ditch your launcher for the steam version, and add cloud sync. This isn't limited to Sims 4. This is ALL EA games on steam. Your DRM is ruining your games. 3,000,000+ people have a steam deck, you're missing an opportunity for DLC sales, and more importantly you are souring the relationship you've already tainted with your community. Amen or whatever

Long-time player of the Sims franchise, starting all the way back with the Sims 2 on PS2, and this is the best title so-far. My only gripe I've got with the game isn't necessarily the game itself, but the DLC. This game has been out for almost ten years now, and the first packs that came out are still the same price they were at launch. This is the same issue COD titles have with their pricing, 10+ year old games still selling for $40+ (And even upwards of $60). If the prices were adjusted to match the age of the game (Plus with the recent announcement of development of TS5) I'd probably be inclined to pay the actual price versus going to G-2-A or other discount key sites for expansions. Steam needs to put a middle-ground recommendation for reviews like this, I can't really recommend the game if you plan on buying expansions but if you're playing just the base game I 100% recommend it.

The base game lacks a lot of things. I sorta get why sims 4 doesn't have much. The developers are trying to save frames maybe. However the way i see is computers are getting faster and faster and more people are upgrading everyday or so time keeps changing. So sims4 should really look at improving their game and add more things not short DLC's there's hardly any updates besides fixing bugs. The fact you have to buy expansion packs or DLC's to have more things in the game is not worth. I have see many people making private mods or downloading cracked versions of DLC's.  It's not worth buying overpriced DLC's since the game is singleplayer. So many people will continue to pirate the DLC's or mod their version remake sims4. If this game featured online mode where you can play with others in first person or third person then maybe it's worth it I can see the DLC's being worth buying if it was online interactive with others in gameplay.  At this point the sims 4 will probably never have an online mode and i see mostly DLC's will be released.  It's fun to build a sim and house but playing the sim can get very boring. Honestly Roblox version of Sims4 is way better. For example games like RoCitiziens or Bloxburg allows you to build houses and talk to people you could go first person or third person. GTA V RP- role-play does a way better job than sims 4. Since they have proximity chat and features many jobs such as cops, criminals, or other normal civilian jobs. They also have the hunger bar if they don't eat they die and other social bars. In conclusion Sims 4 lacks the experience in the game we get excited about making our sims for hours and building houses. But when we play the game we instantly get BORED and that's just a fact they fail to give sims 4 an experience like maybe driving, skydiving, exploring foreign countries or have proximity chat with other sims. If they wanted to keep the game single-player at least add more interactive activies and not DLC's this game could feature a battlepass like all the other games lol.

A huge downgrade from The Sims 3 imo. It is fine, it has a few improvements like multitasking and the customization is easier and more intuitive, but there's also so much less customization options? You used to be able to change the texture and color to whatever you wanted on everything, like clothes and furniture, now it's just a few choices and you cant get as creative as before. There is like 5 free lots on the map and you cant add more? This is just terrible, you used to be able to edit your world and there were around like 50 lots and you could add and remove them and you could own multiple properties and now what? You can have 5 families at max in one town. I also hate that it isn't open world. Loading screens everywhere. I am sure my computer could handle the TINY map loaded fully at once. The portion of the world that is loaded is so tiny. You used to be able to see the whole world and the sims lived their own lives and actually did things and had drama and stuff. Idk how much does the dlc improve the game, but I am not overflowing with money. TLDR: A lot of feautures from sims 3 were removed and the game is empty and bland. It's one step forward and 2 steps back.

I adore the sims 4, the sims franchise has been lart of my life as a kid, and this game really pushed the boundaries when it came to build buy mode and the depth of gameplay. I will share some of the best and worst packs though (in my opinion) I love: -Get together -Discover University -Cats and Dogs -Cottage Living -Dream Home Decorater -Eco Lifestyle I hate: -Journey to Batuu -Luxury Party -My First Pet Stuff -Almost every kit (they're a ripoff) I am not a fan of the fact they've made the recent additions of inclusive CAS assets DLC rather than base game either. No one should have to pay for their culture. But I will say they're very well made if you're interested in them. Just buy them on sale, don't let them take more money than necessary for that. I first played The Sims 4 years ago, when it was first ported over to PS4. I played it for a few weeks and then moved onto other things, having seen it all before ‚Äì or so I thought. Having spent countless hours on the original The Sims way back when, I was impressed with the evolution, but beyond that I just wanted to get back to the nearest shooter or dungeon crawler. Picking up a new PC in December last year, though, led me to wandering around the lonely aisles of the online storefront. I tend to lurk in Steam for hours, shortcut through the Epic Store when I‚Äôm feeling brave, check in with Microsoft to be sociable, etc. And so it was that I found myself downloading the Origin launcher, against the better judgement of whatever remains of my buyer‚Äôs conscience. And right there was The Sims 4, for the low price of ¬£8.99. The Sims 4 2020 review Now I‚Äôll be honest, my kids have been playing it on PS4 lately and so I had been recently exposed to it and was wondering how much had changed. The one thing I was very aware of was how many content packs, ‚Äústuff packs‚Äù, game packs and expansions had been released since the launch. To download all of it runs into the ¬£100s. With the addition of Tiny Living, offering small building spaces and minimilist props, it seemed a good time to get back into it. With a review code from EA and a handful of packs I bought myself, I decided to re-review The Sims 4 for 2020. Is it worth buying if you never have? Is it worth jumping back into if you‚Äôve long since walked away? The first thing I‚Äôll say is that stuff is important in The Sims 4. I wouldn‚Äôt ever usually recommend anyone spend money on microtransactions or DLC unless you really love the game in question, but if you have a bit of spare cash on the occasions when there‚Äôs an Origin sale or a holiday sale, it‚Äôs worth grabbing a few packs, especially with the base game so often reduced to less than ¬£10. The Sims 4 2020 review I set to work sculpting the GodisaGeek team, an as finely-tuned and well-rounded a group of individuals as any (honest) and dropped four of them into a pair of newly furnished apartments in the San Myshuno neighborhood available with the City Living pack. I had forgotten how much of a joy it is to just sit back and watch these little people go about their business. The Sims, I mean, not the Geek team. I‚Äôm not sure if real life Adam sleeps as much as his Sims 4 counterpart (seriously, the dude went to sleep on the floor of a karaoke bar during a date) [Editor‚Äôs note: all I want to do is sleep, the dating part is the unrealistic part], but leaving them to get on with it is still as much fun as it ever was. But the more stuff you have, the harder it is to control your Sims. They want to play guitar or paint a picture, mix drinks at their mini-bar, or spend hours star-gazing with the telescope. I‚Äôve always found it funny how most Sims have that casual don‚Äôt-give-a-‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• that leads them to just go to bed mid-conversation because they‚Äôre tired, or wander into another Sims house and make dinner. The last big expansion was Island Living, a pack that allows you to either visit the tropical paradise of Sulani, or build a home there and move in. This, along with the City Living and Discover University packs, has done more to change the overall pace and face of The Sims 4 than any of the others. In Island Living you can swim with dolphins, meet mermaids, open a beach bar and live out the kind of fantasies that matter to someone my age. In Discover University you get to have fresh adventures in higher education, while the City Living pack turns The Sims 4 into a more slapstick version of your favourite 30-something sitcoms. The Sims 4 2020 review Having now been around now for almost 6 years and still being supported with new expansions, The Sims 4 is showing no signs of going away and honestly, I‚Äôm here for it. It has the same problems, still, as The Sims has always had with AI and pathfinding, and now and then a Sim will steadfastly refuse to follow any kind of instruction or will stubbornly defy you in ways that make you believe in the possibility of computer sentience, but there‚Äôs so much content now that even if you only stretch to a pack or two here and there, there‚Äôs a ton of stuff to do. You can have kids and outfit their rooms; you can buy romantic props for the garden, build greenhouses, have pets and fall in love while walking them in the dog park. There are restaurants and ice cream parlours and a school of magic, if you‚Äôre that way inclined. The biggest shame is that EA charge so much for the packs. An odd free one here and there wouldn‚Äôt go amiss, especially considering The Sims 4 had a reported 20million unique users as of January of this year. That‚Äôs impressive for a six year old game that isn‚Äôt a MOBA or an MMO. Despite the news that The Sims 5 is likely to release in 2020, there‚Äôs still so much on offer in The Sims 4 that I can‚Äôt imagine needing to move on just yet. Ultimately, The Sims 4 just offers me something different. My usual games are much darker anf more violent affairs, and I‚Äôve always been turned off by the majority of colourful platforms and family titles. But The Sims 4 is something I can just put on and drift around in, hopping between households and locations as the mood takes me. It may not be anything new, but The Sims 4 in 2020 is definitely alive and kicking, and if you‚Äôve got the green to invest in at least one of the bigger DLC packs ‚Äì or even the game packs that provide actual mini campaigns and objectives ‚Äì there‚Äôs enough content to keep you building, buying and living vicariously for a few more years yet.

I've tried to figure out how to write a review for Sims 4, and perhaps sometime I will post up a better review. But in very short: - You NEED to buy at least one expansion pack (frankly, the more the better), because the base game is sort of an empty shell for putting more into. Buying during sales only seems to be highly prevalent in the Sims community, because it gets expensive fast. - If you don't buy a lot of packs, there is a TON of CC that you can get for free across a ton of fan sites. Even if you have all of the packs, there's some truly amazing CC that will enhance your game a ton. - If you're familiar with older Sims titles, Sims 4 has the most in common with Sims 2, but will be VERY different. Sims 4 has a lot of its own fresh takes on the franchise, so while some old loved things are very different, the fresh take has breathed a lot of new life into the Sims.

This is a typical EA title, hobbled by EA's business practices. The Sims 4 is a well thought out, high production quality game, with many details to manage, allowing you to go as deep as you'd like in exploring and customising your Sims' lives. But, without DLCs,  which are priced out of reach, even during Steam sales, the vanilla experience becomes very boring, very quickly. This is difficult. I like playing the game and received it on deep discount, at CA$5.00, but only get it if you are fully aware of the DLC cash grab EA has on offer.

Controls are terrible, it takes tons of research to just understand basic controls. It takes more time to establish a weird, uncomfortable account with EA than to download the game. Origin is gross and weird. Overall, the game is moderately okay, but the producer slams that down to a poor rating with their draconian oversight. I spend $6 on the game on a 90% discount and I immediately regretted it. For more detail, they ask you personal questions that define your character that are just dumb. For instance, it's things like "what kind of person are you at a party?" A) the type to do karaoke B) the type to be the center of attention or C) the type to pull pranks. Those are the three choices, and you cannot change your character's personality after answering this. THEY ARE THE SAME ANSWER. It's extremely difficult to modify any item within the household, which is vaingloriously produced as a "Starter house" even though it is clearly an incredibly expensive property. EA refused my password because they said it was inappropriate, which is just asinine as it was not. They forced me to create an additional account instead of letting me play from Steam. To be clear, I paid for the game on Steam but EA demanded I register it with them, for some reason. It's just typical EA business, nothing new. If you are willing to fight through EA nonsense to play a mostly subpar game, it might be worth it. For me, at 90% discount, I don't think it is worth it. I pay $6 for this game and I feel that is extraordinarily generous. As far as customization, this is a massive downgrade from Sims III. This game requires you to wear certain outfits that conform with their decisions of what is appropriate. For instance, you cannot wear socks when it is hot. You can wear a sweater while exercising, however there are only a few colors that are deemed appropriate. You cannot wear jeans to sleep, during hot weather, for formal wear, etc. The vast, vast majority of clothing options have less than five color choices. You cannot choose the color yourself. Honestly it's not surprising, EA probably charges extra for color packs as opposed to you choosing the color yourself. You want to wear jeans? You can wear black jeans, light blue jeans, or dark blue jeans. Any other options are locked behind a paywall. If you choose to skip the tutorial, the game refuses your request and immediately forces you into a tutorial. Again, this is typical EA and should be expected. It's not a bad game, but EA sets such a low bar of standards than anything you might want to do is restricted by paywalls. Even then, things as common as snapbacks are portrayed as a weird furry-Brookyln style hybrid. Honestly, it would be one thing if they restricted color. Another if they restricted content. Another if they produced content poorly. But EA restricts each of these things and, as insult to injury, doesn't even make the content look remotely passable. Not a terrible game, but not great, and EA's famous paywalls make it that much poorer.

Very glad the game is free now, even though I paid full price for the special edition back in 2014. Been playing all of The Sims series since the first release of The Sims in 2000, and it's been nothing more than silly fun. The Sims has changed tremendously for the good and the bad, but at the end of the day, it's still The Sims. I am going into adulthood now and barely have time to enjoy it as I would like to. My younger sister, who is 14 (at the moment of this review), also loves The Sims and now has the opportunity to play the collection I've purchased throughout the years without spending a dime (or yen) when I'm sharing my account with her; I agree that the prices of the add-ons are a bit ridiculous. I recommend The Sims only if you've been with it for a while or would like more out of The Sims besides it being free. The expansions are pricey, but it's been like that since the beginning of the franchise. If that's an issue, then I would recommend you look elsewhere.

The sequel to my most favored game (The Sims 3), The Sims 4 does not hold the same energy and steaks that the third title brought and introduced into the series, though, at the same time, it was a risky move either way. The Sims 4 returned to the limited world scope instead of being a singular town map that transitioned more smoother and did not rely on loading screens. However, the screen loads are much quicker than in The Sims 2. There are also fewer traits available to select, with around four at the max and almost 6 in its previous title if you have the University Life DLC. Initially, the game had no toddlers and not much content available at launch (even less offered than its predecessor). Death was not too hard to find or accomplish with any action attempted resulting it, but now it is less so luckily since the title came to Steam this year. With each new announced DLC, it has brought in more options and helps strengthen the title from its basic and its lack of content in the base game. The modding community has also helped add more layers to the game, such as going to school, hairstyles, maps, and even occupations such as resort owning, just like in The Sims 3's DLC Island Paradise. With fresh eyes on The Sims 4, it has differently improved from its launch and was much more entertaining the second go around. However, it still does not top what The Sims 3 brought to the table for me. 9.4/10 :D
